{{distinguish|text=[[Wall Street (1987 film)|Wall Street 1 (film)]]; [[PowerBook G3|Wallstreet 1 (computer)]]; or [[48 Wall Street, Manhattan|48 Wall Street]], also known as the Bank of New York Building}} {{Infobox building |name = 1 Wall Street |status = Complete |image = 1 Wall Street panoramic.jpg |image_size = 225px |caption = 1 Wall Street from east in 2010 |location = 1 Wall St., [[Manhattan|New York]], [[New York (state)|NY]] 10286, [[United States]] |coordinates = {{coord|40|42|26|N|74|00|42|W|type:landmark_region:US-NY|display=inline,title}} |map_type = Lower Manhattan#New York#USA |pushpin_label =1 Wall Street |start_date = 1929 |completion_date = 1931 |architect = [[Ralph Thomas Walker|Ralph Walker]] |owner = Macklowe Properties |floor_area = {{convert|1,165,645|sqft|abbr=on}}<ref>{{cite web|title=One Wall Street|url=http://www.skyscrapercenter.com/building/one-wall-street/1727|website=Skyscraper Center|publisher=CTBUH|accessdate=11 September 2017}}</ref> |top_floor = |floor_count = 50 |references = |building_type = Commercial Office | architectural_style = [[art deco]] |roof = 654 feet (199 meters) |elevator_count = |structural_engineer= |main_contractor = |opening = |developer = |management = }} {{external media | width = 210px | float = right | headerimage= [[File:One-wall-street-windows.jpg|210px]] | video1 = [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vPLms_sMvQE&list=TLGGIit1IFpuZWEwNjAzMjAxNw Tour an Art Deco Masterpiece, The Daily 360 ], ''[[The New York Times]]'' | accessdate =March 6, 2017 }}
'''One Wall Street''' (originally the '''[[Irving Trust Company]] Building''', then the '''[[Bank of New York]] Building''' after 1988, and now known as the '''BNY Mellon Building''' since 2007), is an [[Art-Deco]]-style skyscraper in [[Lower Manhattan]], [[New York City]]. It is located in [[Manhattan]]'s [[Financial District, Manhattan|Financial District]] on the corner of [[Wall Street]] and [[Broadway (Manhattan)|Broadway]]. Up until September 30, 2015, it served as the global headquarters of [[The Bank of New York Mellon]] Corporation. In May, 2014, the bank sold the building to a joint venture led by [[Harry B. Macklowe]]'s Macklowe Properties for $585 million.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2014-05-21/bny-mellon-reaches-deal-for-585-million-office-sale | work=Bloomberg | first=David M | last=Levitt | title=BNY Mellon Reaches Deal for $585 Million Office Sale | date=May 22, 2014}}</ref>
== Architecture== Designed by [[Ralph Thomas Walker|Ralph Walker]], the building was originally built for the Irving Trust Company. It is an [[Art Deco]] architectural style, with a [[steel frame|steel skeleton]] whose [[facade]] is covered in [[limestone]].<ref>[http://ci.columbia.edu/0240s/0242_3/0242_3_s2_7_text.html Columbia class text]</ref> Because of the curves in the wall, the bank does not completely occupy its full building lot. By municipal law, unoccupied and unmarked land would revert to the public, which is the reason for a number of small markers embedded in the sidewalk asserting the limits of the building's lot. It counts fifty stories (originally planned for 46),<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/19689774/news_of_bankers_and_banks/|title=News of Bankers and Banks|last=|first=|date=1928-05-02|work=Brooklyn Eagle|access-date=2018-04-30|language=en|via=[[Newspapers.com]] {{OpenAccess}}}}</ref> stands 654 feet (199 meters) tall, and measures 1,165,659 rentable square feet. [[File:48-wall-street2.jpg|thumb|upright|Entrance to One Wall Street]] The Wall Street entrance leads into a two-story banking hall whose ceiling is decorated with red and gold mosaics designed by [[Hildreth Meiere]], comparable to the mosaics in the Golden Hall of [[Stockholm City Hall]], and manufactured by the same company, the [[Ravenna Mosaic Company]] in Berlin.<ref>[http://www.nyu.edu/classes/finearts/nyc/wall/irving.html NYU class description]</ref>
==History==
The previous high-rise on this corner, also called '''One Wall Street''', was erected in 1907 as a slender 18-story office building. The investors, a syndicate from St. Louis, headed by Festus Wade of the St Louis Mercantile Trust Company, paid $700,000 for the 1,131 square foot property, before construction costs.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/19689547/sale_of_chimney_building_plot_recalls/|title=Sale of Chimney Building Plot Recalls Ownership of Late Benjamin D. Silliman|last=|first=|date=1928-02-09|work=Brooklyn Eagle|access-date=2018-04-30|language=en|via=[[Newspapers.com]] {{OpenAccess}}}}</ref> The architects were [[Barnett, Haynes & Barnett]] of St. Louis.<ref>{{cite web|title=When Downtown Real Estate Turned Upward|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/08/10/realestate/when-downtown-real-estate-turned-upward.html|website=New York Times|accessdate=26 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Number One Wall Street|date=16 June 1906|publisher=Real Estate Record and Builders' Guide, Volume 77|page=1140|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6bzO6uzqcqkC&pg=PA1140|accessdate=26 April 2018}}</ref> Known as the "'''Chimney Building'''"<ref name=":0" /> or "'''Chimney Corner'''",<ref name=":1" /> it was acquired and razed as part of Irving Trust's real estate consolidation around 1929. Irving Trust was then known as American Exchange Irving Trust, and it bought the original corner property along with a number of adjacent lots on either side, to create a 180 foot frontage along Broadway, and the entire block along Wall Street.<ref name=":1" /> The "chimney" property was at that time the costliest transaction per square foot recorded in the city, at $1,050,000.
Construction on the present building began in 1929 and was completed in 1931,<ref name=desrep /> to the designs of the architectural firm of [[Voorhees, Gmelin and Walker]]. A time study of the construction was photographed form the vantage point of the [[Trinity Court Building]] a block away.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://cca.qc.ca/en/collection/525-irving-trust-building-new-york|title=Irving Trust Building, New York {{!}} Canadian Centre for Architecture (CCA)|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100914231838/http://www.cca.qc.ca/en/collection/525-irving-trust-building-new-york|archive-date=2010-09-14|access-date=2010-02-04|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
Between 1963 and 1965,<ref name="desrep">[[New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission]] [http://www.neighborhoodpreservationcenter.org/db/bb_files/2001OneWallStreet.pdf "One Wall Street Designation Report"] (March 6, 2001)</ref> a 36-floor addition to the site was constructed to the south of the tower to provide extra office space. This site had been occupied by the eighteen-story [[Manhattan Life Insurance Building]] (1894), which was the title-holder as the tallest building in the world from 1894 until 1899,<ref>{{cite book | last = Korom | first = Joseph A. | year = 2008 | title = The American skyscraper, 1850-1940: a celebration of height | publisher = Branden Books | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=JVzYO1TyZ6AC&lpg=PA198&dq=%22Manhattan%20Life%20Insurance%20Building%22&pg=PA198#v=onepage&q=%22Manhattan%20Life%20Insurance%20Building%22&f=false | isbn = 978-0-8283-2188-4 | page = 432 }}</ref> and the twenty-two story Knickerbocker Trust Company Building (1909). Among other alterations was the chiseling out of "Irving Trust" name from the cornerstone and replacement with "Bank of New York." The last owner of the Chimney Building, the Central Union Trust Company, had also owned the Manhattan Life building, and had moved there in 1929 upon the sale to Irving.<ref name=":1" />
The building has had numerous problems with the limestone exterior, and in 2001, the building's owners decided to bring in [[Hoffmann Architects]] to conduct a survey of the exterior and provide a five-year masterplan consisting of mortar repair and window replacements.
After the sale to Macklowe Properties, it was reported that the building would be converted to [[condominium]]s, rental apartments, and retail space.<ref>http://ny.curbed.com/archives/2014/11/20/macklowe_to_convert_one_wall_street_into_condos_and_rentals.php</ref>
==See also== *[[List of tallest buildings in New York City]] *[[National Register of Historic Places listings in New York County, New York]] *[[List of New York City Designated Landmarks in Manhattan]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{Commons category |1 Wall Street}} *[https://www.1wallst.com/ Building Website] *[http://www.in-arch.net/NYC/nyc2b.html#36 in-Arch.net: The Irving Trust Co. Building] * Rare slideshow of images showing the construction of the Irving Trust Building - {{Cite web|url=http://cca.qc.ca/en/collection/525-irving-trust-building-new-york|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100914231838/http://www.cca.qc.ca/en/collection/525-irving-trust-building-new-york|title=Irving Trust Building, New York {{!}} Canadian Centre for Architecture (CCA)|archive-date=2010-09-14|access-date=2010-02-04|dead-url=yes|df=}} {{Broadway (Manhattan)}}

{{Infobox person |name = Ashish Bhasin |image = Ashish Bhasin.jpg }}
'''Ashish Bhasin''', Chairman & CEO - South Asia, [[Dentsu Aegis Network]], and also a member of the Dentsu Aegis Network Asia Pacific Executive Board, is a globally recognised media veteran.<ref>Federation of Indian Chambers of Commerce & Industry [http://www.ficci-frames.com/frames/speakers/Ashish_Bhasin.pdf], FICCI</ref> He has been part of the Media, Advertising & Marketing community – especially representing India and the Asia Pacific market - for the past 30 years.<ref>Federation of Indian Chambers of Commerce & Industry [http://www.ficci-frames.com/frames/speakers/Ashish_Bhasin.pdf], FICCI</ref> He is frequently featured as a thought leader in the advertising industry on print and television platforms such as [[The Economic Times]],<ref>Gaurav Laghate, [http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/industry/media/entertainment/media-industry-gapes-at-a-loss-of-rs-1500-crore-in-advertising-money/articleshow/55726744.cms], ''[[The Economic Times]]'', December 1, 2016</ref> Brand Equity,<ref>Priyanka Nair , [http://brandequity.economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/advertising/dans-ashish-bhasin-is-happy-because-his-competitors-underestimated-him-heres-why/55613012], ''Brand Equity'', November 25, 2016</ref><ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tCLUU1R9Occ</ref> and [[Daily News and Analysis|DNA]].<ref>Ashish Tiwari , [http://www.dnaindia.com/money/report-ad-firms-see-rs-2000-cr-business-loss-on-demonetization-2278259], ''[[Daily News and Analysis]]'', November 30, 2016</ref> He represented [[India]] as a member of the jury at the 63rd [[Cannes Lions International Festival of Creativity]].<ref>[http://brandequity.economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/advertising/prasoon-joshi-josy-paul-ashish-bhasin-and-10-other-indians-on-jury-of-cannes-lions-2016/51943998], ''[[Brand Equity]]'', April 22, 2016</ref> Bhasin has also served as India's cultural Ambassador to Pennsylvania, USA in 1992 under an exclusive Rotary programme.<ref>Federation of Indian Chambers of Commerce & Industry [http://www.ficci-frames.com/frames/speakers/Ashish_Bhasin.pdf], FICCI</ref>
==Early career== He served as Managing Director of Lintas Initiative Outdoor Advertising Private Limited (also known as Aaren Initiative Outdoor Advertising Private Limited). He was the President and Director of Integrated Marketing Action Group at SSC&B Lintas Private Limited, as well as, the Asia Regional Director for Integral Marketing at Lowe & Partners Worldwide Limited. At Lintas IMAG, he oversaw eight specialised companies – Linterland for rural marketing, Lintas Personal for CRM and direct marketing, LINOpinion for public relations, Advent for events, Lintertainment for entertainment marketing, Lintas Healthcare for healthcare marketing, dCell for strategic design, and Aaren Initiative for out-of-home. His stints include handling the [[Hindustan Unilever]] account in seven Asian countries, managing operations in various Lintas India offices, and running the show as President at Initiative Media.<ref>[https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=13008863&privcapId=98367162|title= Company Overview of Aegis Media India Private Limited], ''[[Bloomberg L.P.]]''</ref>
==Career with Dentsu Aegis Network==
Bhasin began his career with Dentsu in June 2008.<ref>AFAQS! News Bureau, [http://www.afaqs.com/news/story/41300_Dentsus-Ashish-Bhasin-wins-2014-Business-Excellence-Award-for-Media-CEO-of-the-Year---India], ''afaqs.com'', July 7, 2014</ref> In 2012, the Dentsu Aegis Network was formed after the Japanese advertising giant [[Dentsu]] bought over the UK based Aegis group for a reported $5 billion, as reported by the [[Wall Street Journal]].<ref>Kenneth Maxwell, Suzanne Vranica and Hiroyuki Kachi, [https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702303740704577522103894109834], ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'', July 12, 2012</ref> By June 2015, the Dentsu Aegis Network consolidated its India operations under him. He has built the Dentsu Aegis Network in India from a 50 member team to a 3000 member powerhouse, now the 2nd largest Advertising and Marketing Communications Group in India, overturning for the first time the existing ranking, which has historically been in place for over 80 years. He has setup multiple creative shops like Taproot Dentsu, agencies under the Dentsu umbrella; media brands Carat and Vizeum and a battery of digital outfits including Webchutney, Isobar and WATconsult.<ref>Ravi Balakrishnan, [http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/magazines/brand-equity/ashish-bhasin-confident-dentsu-aegis-will-be-no-2-only-to-wpp-by-2017-his-competitors-differ/articleshow/47971425.cms], ''[[The Economic Times]]'', July 8, 2015</ref>
DAN India currently comprises companies such as Carat, Dentsu, Dentsu Media, Dentsu Impact, Dentsu India, Dentsu One, iProspect, Isobar, Posterscope,The StoryLab, Vizeum, Amnet, Milestone Brandcom, Dentsu Communications, Dentsu Marcom, Dentsu Creative Impact, Dentsu Taproot, Dentsu Web Chutney and Dentsu Media.<ref>Pritha Mitra Dasgupta,[http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/industry/services/advertising/dentsu-aegis-consolidates-india-business-under-ashish-bhasin/articleshow/47521889.cms], ''[[The Economic Times]]'', June 3, 2015</ref> In a short span of 2 years, under his leadership and guidance, the Dentsu Aegis Network has acquired a number of diverse media firms such as Perfect Relations,<ref>Saumya Tewari, [http://www.livemint.com/Companies/YrPagdGKWa1eqZ5Qos88jP/Dentsu-Aegis-acquires-PR-firm-Perfect-Relations.html], ''[[Mint (newspaper)|Mint]]'', September 20, 2016</ref> Fountainhead MKTG <ref>Pritha Mitra Dasguptai, [http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/industry/services/advertising/dentsu-aegis-buys-fountainhead-entertainment-in-rs-300-400-crore-deal/articleshow/49446844.cms], ''[[The Economic Times]]'', October 19, 2015</ref>, WATConsult <ref>BS Reporter, [http://www.business-standard.com/article/companies/dentsu-aegis-network-acquires-majority-stake-watconsult-115013000588_1.html], ''[[Business Standard]]'', January 30, 2015</ref>, and Happy Creative, a boutique agency based out of Bangalore.<ref>Gaurav Laghate, [http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/industry/services/advertising/dentsu-to-acquire-happy-creative-for-rs-200-300-crore/articleshow/54771106.cms], ''[[The Economic Times]]'', October 11, 2016</ref> According to [[The Economic Times]], the network today is the 2nd largest Advertising and Marketing Communications Group in India, overturning for the first time the existing ranking, which has historically been in place for over 80 years.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/magazines/brand-equity/how-dentsu-aegis-network-went-on-to-become-the-no-2-advertising-network-in-india/articleshow/57391034.cms|title=How Dentsu Aegis Network went on to become the No 2 advertising network in India|last=Irani|first=Delshad|date=2017-03-01|work=The Economic Times|access-date=2017-11-17|last2=Balakrishnan|first2=Ravi|last3=Bapna|first3=Amit}}</ref>
==Recognition== Ashish has received the Campaign Asia - South Asia Agency Head of the Year award 2017, 2016 and 2015 and was selected as MXM’s Media Person of the Year- 2016. He has been awarded the 2015 IAA Leadership Award for Media Agency Head of the Year and was the Exchange4Media - Hallmark Chairman of the Year 2015. He is also the recipient of the Business Excellence Awards for Media CEO of the Year - India & Chairman of the Year – India 2013, 2014 and 2015, at UK’s Business Excellence Awards. He has received the Indira Super Achiever Award 2003 and was also adjudged “Media Marketer of the Year” at the Brief Media Awards
== Other Interests == He has been appointed Head of Jury for the Asia Pacific Effie Awards 2017. He has served on several global juries including Cannes Lion 2016, Cannes Lion 2007, Dubai Lynx 2008, Festival of Media Global 2013 at Montreux and Asia’s Most Promising Brands and Leaders 2013 in Dubai. He was Chairman - National Marketing Committee and Mumbai Chapter Chair of CII’s Young Indians Group and was India’s Cultural Ambassador to Pennsylvania, USA in 1992 under a Rotary Exchange Programme. He conceived & founded the Post Graduate Programme at North Point.
Ashish serves or has served on most industry bodies in India, including as Chairman Goafest 2017, Co-Chairman of the AAAI – IBF committee, Vice-President of AAAI, Chairman Media Abbys 2012 & 2013, former Chairman of the Readership Studies Council of India and Board of Governors of MRUC. He is also the Founding Chairman of the [[Sydenham Institute of Management Studies, Research and Entrepreneurship Education|Sydenham Institute of Management]]’s Alumni Association, amongst others
In 2017, he was elected chairman of the board of Media Research Users Council (MRUC), the body that oversees the [[Indian Readership Survey]] (IRS).
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links==
{{DEFAULTSORT:Bhasin, Ashish}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Advertising people]]

{{refimprove|date=February 2018}}
The '''Administration of the Autonomous Communities''', also known as '''Autonomous Administration''', is a [[Public Administration of Spain]]. It belongs to the second level of the Public Administrations, because it exerts its powers within the limits of each [[Autonomous communities of Spain|Autonomous Community]].
It is integrated by:
* Central Organization (Government of the Autonomous Community or Council of Government, the President of the Autonomous Communities, the Vicepresident and the Councilors). * Peripheral Administration (Territorial Delegations of the Autonomous Communities, Sectoral Delegations of the Government Departments).
The Autonomic Administration has a very broad level of competence, based on the [[decentralization |decentralization]] of the State or through the State of Autonomies. As for the level of competences, they are not always the same, and are regulated in each [[Statute of Autonomy]] for each [[Autonomous Community]], making in some cases the level of competences is higher than those of a [[Federal state]].
It should also be taken into account that the Autonomous Community has its own [[legislative body]], and that the autonomous administration must behave before it like any other [[executive power]], respecting the rules issued by its autonomous parliament.
In the [[Spanish Constitution of 1978]] it is regulated in Chapter Three, entitled "of the Autonomous Communities". This Chapter regulates the form of creation and authorization of the Autonomous Communities, the elaboration of its Statutes, the powers transferred to the Autonomous Communities, the powers of the State, its resources and its financing.
==Structure== Like the [[General State Administration]], the Autonomous Administration is regulated by Law 40/2015 and the structure is practically the same.<ref>[https://www.boe.es/buscar/act.php?id=BOE-A-2015-10566 Ley 40/2015, de 1 de octubre, de Régimen Jurídico del Sector Público.]</ref> However, it can vary from one Autonomous Community to another depending on the provisions in the Statute of Autonomy. Here the common organs are exposed:
===Central Organization=== ====Government==== The Autonomous Government is the executive power of the [[Autonomous community of Spain|Autonomous Community]]. As in the [[Government of Spain|Central Government]] it responds before its [[parliament]] (autonomic parliament). The Government directs the Autonomous Administration within its competences.
Contrary to what happens with the Central Government, the decisions taken by the Executive are not sanctioned by the [[King of spain|King]], and it is the President of the Autonomous Community who signs the laws and decisions on his behalf.
====President==== The President of the Autonomous Community is the head of the executive power as well as the highest authority of the Autonomous Community. He directs the Autonomous Government, elects its Vice President and Councilors and decides the policies that the government carries out.
As at the State level, the President may elect more than one Vice President and may freely separate his Vice-Presidents and Councilors. If the President is ceased, they cease with him.
====Councilors==== The Councilors of the Autonomous Community are like the [[Minister (government)|Ministers]] of the Central Government. They lead a ''Consejería'' (government department as a [[Ministry (government department)|Ministry]]). Councilor work in their governamental area and appoint the members of their department like Vice Councilors, General Directors...etc
The figure of the Vice Councilor or Deputy Councilor is not always present, because it is the decision of the Councilor to exist or not this position and, in Autonomous Communities of small size where the work is not much, often these positions do not exist.
====General Directors==== The General Directorates are management departmental bodies and steering bodies, hierarchically inferior to the Councilors or Vice Councirlos (if they exist). The holder must have a degree of competence and professional experience, and will be selected from career officials of the State, Autonomous Communities or Local entities, also demanding the title of Doctor, Licensee, Engineer, Architect or equivalent. It should be noted that the Royal Decree on the structure of the Department may omit the first requirement because it is a General Directorate whose exceptional characteristics require that the holder does not have the status of official of the State.
====Cabinets==== They are consultation bodies generally composed of a technical secretary and several technicians who support the President, Vicepresident, Councilors, ect. in their relations with institutions, in making decisions and performing special advisory tasks in a particular branch of knowledge.
===Peripheral Administration=== ====Territorial Delegations==== The Territorial Delegations of the Autonomous Communities carry out the same activity as the Delegations of the Central Government. They are administrative bodies whose head is a high position appointed in the discretion of the Autonomous Government. He is in charge of the management of the Autonomous Administration in some of the territorial divisions of the Autonomous Communities, such as the [[Provinces of Spain|Province]].
====Sectoral Delegations==== The Sectoral Delegations of the Consejerías are organs that represent the different Departments of an autonomous government. The holder must have a degree of competence and professional experience, and will be selected from career officials of the State, Autonomous Communities or Local entities, also demanding the title of Doctor, Licensee, Engineer, Architect or equivalent
==External links== * [http://www.seat.mpr.gob.es/portal/areas/politica_autonomica/info_basica/organiz_institucional_basica.html Organization of each Autonomous Community] * [http://www.seat.mpr.gob.es/portal/areas/politica_autonomica/Estatutos_Autonomia/est_autonomia.html Statutes of Autonomy of each Autonomous Community]
==See also== * [[Public Administration of Spain]] * [[General State Administration]] * [[Government of Spain]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Public Administration of Spain]] [[Category:Public administration]] [[Category:Public policy]] [[Category:Autonomous communities of Spain]] [[Category:Decentralization]]

{{multiple issues| {{BLP sources|date=November 2010}} {{notability|bio|date=November 2010}} }}
'''Axel Miller''' (born 20 February 1965, [[Uccle]], [[Belgium]]) is a [[Belgium|Belgian]] businessman. From January 2006 to September 2008, he was [[chief executive officer]] and chairman of the Management Board of [[Dexia]] S.A. Since 2009, he is partner of Petercam, a Belgian financial group, active in private banking, institutional asset management and corporate finance.
== Early life == Axel Miller's mother was a chemist and his father a biochemist. He spent his childhood between France, England, and Belgium.<ref name="dieteren 855615530cae">{{cite web|url=http://www.dieteren.com/sites/default/files/bio_miller_axel_95572c06-0b78-480a-bcee-855615530cae.pdf|title=Biography|website=Dieteren.com|accessdate=11 September 2017}}</ref>
In 1987, Axel Miller obtained a master's degree in [[Law]] from the [[Université Libre de Bruxelles]] (ULB), [[Brussels]], [[Belgium]].<ref name="dieteren 855615530cae"/>
==Career== Axel Miller started his career in 1987 as a lawyer working for the legal firm ''Simont & Simont''. In 1988, he worked in Alain Minc's team in the failed hostile IPO launched on the Générale de Belgique. In September 1990, he joined [[Davis Polk & Wardwell]], first in [[New York City|New York]] ([[United States]]) then in [[Paris]] ([[France]]). He went to work as a lawyer at the bar in Brussels in January 1991. In December 1991, he started working for ''Stibbe Simont Monahan Duhot'' in Brussels, where he became a partner in 1996, a member of the recruitment committee and then member of the Management Board. In 1995, he was among the lawyers that worked on the merger of Crédit Communal de Belgique and Crédit Local de France to create [[Dexia]]. As soon as 1997, he became an adviser to Dexia and to its CEO, Pierre Richard, and played an active role in the acquisition of the [[Banque Internationale à Luxembourg]] in 1999, [[Financial Security Assurance]] in 2000 and Artesia in 2001. In May 1999, he joined ''Clifford Chance'' in Brussels as a partner.<ref name="dieteren 855615530cae"/><ref name="levif pdf">{{cite web|url=http://actions.trends.levif.be/actions/trends/manager-de-lannee/files/2006-axel-miller.pdf|title=Manager de l’Année|website=Levif.be|date=11 January 2007|author=Sébastien Buron|language=fr|accessdate=11 September 2017}}</ref>
He joined the Dexia Group in 2001 as General Counsel.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dexia.com/EN/journalist/press_releases/Pages/Axel-Miller-rejoint-le-groupe-en-tant-que-General-Counsel---Bruno-Deletr%C3%A9-entre-au-directoire-de-Dexia-Cr%C3%A9dit-Local.aspx|title=Axel Miller joins the Dexia Group as General Counsel - Bruno Deletré joins the Executive Board of Dexia Crédit Local|website=Dexia.com|date=18 May 2001|accessdate=11 September 2017}}</ref> Upon his arrival, he was in charge of merging the activities of three banks: Dexia Bank, Bacob Bank and Paribas Bank Belgium. In January 2002, he became a member of the Management Board of Dexia Bank, and in January 2003 he became Chairman of the Management Board of Dexia Bank and Head of Personal Financial Services at Group level. Axel Miller is Vice-President of the Belgian Banking Association and a member of the Board of Directors of [[Febelfin]]. He is also a Director of several Dexia Group companies, of {{Interlanguage link multi|Ethias|nl}}, of [[Crédit du Nord]] and of [[Carmeuse]] Holding.
In 2006, Axel Miller became the CEO of [[Dexia]]. In June 2006, he led the acquisition of Turkish [[DenizBank]]. As head of Dexia, he also had to deal with the [[Lernout & Hauspie]] affair.<ref name="levif pdf"/> Following the [[subprime mortgage crisis]], Axel Miller resigned on 30 September 2008. In 2009, he became a partner of Petercam, a Belgian financial group, active in private banking, institutional asset management and corporate finance.<ref name="dieteren 855615530cae"/> In August 2013, he was appointed CEO of D'Ieteren, a major car distributor in Western Europe.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dieteren.com/en/newsroom/group/2013/axel-miller-succeed-jean-pierre-bizet-managing-director-ceo-dieteren|title=Axel Miller to succeed to Jean-Pierre Bizet as managing director - CEO of D'Ieteren|website=Dieteren.com|date=1 August 2013|accessdate=11 September 2017}}</ref>
==Bailout== On 30 September 2008 the Belgian, French and Luxembourg governments said they would put in 6.4bn euros ($9bn; £5bn) into keep Dexia afloat.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/7643638.stm |title=Business | Second Belgian bank gets bail-out |publisher=BBC News |date=2008-09-30 |accessdate=2013-08-16}}</ref> On the same day at 10:02am the BBC News Channel broke news which had come from the news provider AFP "Dexia Chairman and the Chief Executive resign after bailout". This was later confirmed live on the BBC News Channel from Brussels at 10:24am. Axel Miller and Pierre Richard were Chairman and Chief Executive respectively.
{{refnec|text=A Belgian parlemential commission concluded after a deep investigation that the former CEO of Dexia failed to do his job and was responsible for the bailout of Dexia|date=September 2017}}.
== Personal life == Axel Miller is married to Catherine Duhen. They have four children together.<ref name="dieteren 855615530cae"/>
==References== {{Reflist}}<!--added above External links/Sources by script-assisted edit-->
{{Authority control}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2011}}

revision.text:
[[File:Bob logo.jpg|thumb|logo BOB]] '''Best of Biotech''' (''BOB'') is an international business plan competition with focus on life sciences, i.e. [[Biotechnology]], [[Medical technology]] and related fields. The competition is organized every 1–2 years by LISA ([[Life Science Austria]]), a program run by [[Austria Wirtschaftsservice]], the Austrian federal development and financing bank, to promote entrepreneurship in the life science sector. The competition is co-sponsored by private life science and healthcare companies and is organized in partnership with international tech transfer agencies and business incubators.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.staatspreis.at/Satellite.aspx?&143=606&145=162&35=606&8=17&109=2|title=LISA awards|accessdate=2009-07-22|work=Staatspreis|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100306183557/http://www.staatspreis.at/Satellite.aspx|archivedate=2010-03-06|df=}}</ref>
==History== Since the first contest in 2000, 211 projects teams have participated, 41 companies have been founded and around €170,000 in prize money has been awarded. Among the companies founded are [[Ayoxxa Biosystems|AYOXXA Biosystems]], AVIR Green Hills Biotechnology, Oridis Biomed, Protaffin AG and Ugichem.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bioportfolio.com/biocorporate/19302-best+of+biotech.html|title=Best of Biotech information|accessdate=2009-02-08|work=Bioportfolio.com}}</ref><ref name="Straits Times 2011"/><ref name="Basu 2011"/>
==Competition== The contest is divided into two phases: In the first phase, participants submit a business idea of which the best three are awarded a cash prize. The second phase includes workshops and coaching sessions, which enable the participants to translate their business ideas into professional business plans. The best three business plans as well as the best medical technology business plan are finally awarded cash prizes. The competition is open to participants from all countries.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://derstandard.at/fs/3128449|title=Plane mit BOB|accessdate=2009-07-22|work=Der Standard}}</ref>
The 2010 Jury had the following members: G. Aichinger (Baxter), J. Sarx (Austria Wirtschaftsservice), E. Prieschl-Grassauer ([[Marinomed]]), T. von Rüden, M. Fritz (Austria Wirtschaftsservice), M. Müller (MUW), A. Weinländer-Mölders (Caesar & Loretz), R. Hodits (Wellington Partners), M. Jung (Earlybird), A. Fehér (Convincive Consulting), J. Rothe (Life Science Partners), J. Kosch (MIG Fonds)
== References == {{reflist|refs=
<ref name="Straits Times 2011">{{cite news |title=Powerful disease detecting chip |first= |last= |url=http://newshub.nus.edu.sg/news/1110/PDF/BEST-st-23oct-p20&21.pdf |newspaper=[[The Straits Times]] |location=Singapore |date=October 23, 2011 |accessdate=Apr 2, 2014 |page=News section |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140414021830/http://newshub.nus.edu.sg/news/1110/PDF/BEST-st-23oct-p20%2621.pdf |archivedate=2014-04-14 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
<ref name="Basu 2011">{{cite news |title=Testing time for biotech scientist, A biochip that can detect hundreds of diseases |first=Radha |last=Basu |url=http://newshub.nus.edu.sg/news/1101/PDF/BIOTECH-st-1jan-pD4.pdf |newspaper= The Straits Times |location=Singapore |date= January 1, 2011 |accessdate= Apr 2, 2014 |page= D4|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140413192311/http://newshub.nus.edu.sg/news/1101/PDF/BIOTECH-st-1jan-pD4.pdf |archivedate= 2014-04-13|deadurl=no}}</ref>
}}

revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{notability|Organizations|date=January 2010}} {{advert|date=January 2010}} }}
[[File:BOB logo 72dpi.jpg|thumb|300px|BOB's Logo, created by Vancouver-based Karo in 2006]] '''Building Opportunities with Business Inner-City Society''' (AKA Building Opportunities with Business or BOB) is a non-profit organization that has been active in [[Vancouver]]'s [[Downtown Eastside]], Chinatown, Strathcona, Mt Pleasant, Gastown and Downtown South areas since October 2005. BOB's goal according to its website is "to support local business development and increase job opportunities for inner-city residents by championing an inclusive revitalization process".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.buildingopportunities.org/ |title=BOB | Building Opportunities with Business |publisher=Buildingopportunities.org |date= |accessdate=2010-07-26}}</ref>
==Creating BOB== [[File:BOBinnercity.png|thumb|left|300px|Vancouver's inner city. The dark grey areas are where BOB's efforts are focused as per the Vancouver Agreement.]] The creation of BOB came as a direct result of the Vancouver Agreement<ref name="vancouveragreement">{{cite web|url=http://www.vancouveragreement.ca/TheAgreement.htm|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050316205956/http://www.vancouveragreement.ca/TheAgreement.htm|archive-date=2005-03-16|dead-url=yes|title=TheAgreement|accessdate=2014-02-05|df=}}</ref> an urban development initiative between the governments of Canada, British Columbia, and the City of Vancouver. BOB's role as defined by the agreement is to promote business development, offer mentoring and employment training as well as administering a loans program to inner-city small businesses.<ref name="vancouveragreement2">{{cite web|url=http://www.vancouveragreement.ca/EconomicDevelopment.htm|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051125000156/http://www.vancouveragreement.ca/EconomicDevelopment.htm|archive-date=2005-11-25|dead-url=yes|title=EconomicDevelopment|accessdate=2014-02-05|df=}}</ref> In the time since its creation the organization has developed from being seen largely as an employment agency into being recognized as a credible and reliable source for a variety of information on the DTES. Separating itself from the legacy or failures of PEACH, the economic development and job creation organization that BOB was created to replace and distinguishing itself as a separate and unique entity has been a challenge to the organization. While some of the people and resources from PEACH were transferred to BOB the organization was created as a comprehensive new service to address the needs of business and employment. Fast Track to Employment (FTE)another organization active in the DTES has remained its own agency working in tandem with BOB. With a mandate to create employment opportunities by working with employers and residents FTE operates within the BOB offices as an affiliated or sister charitable organization sharing the same board of directors as BOB.
BOB as an organization has made efforts in the media to clarify its role in the DTES while addressing a diverse range of policy and planning issues relevant to Vancouver's inner-city such as STIR (Short Term Incentives for Rental Housing)<ref>Stir is a step in the right direction, Shirley Chan, ''Vancouver Sun'', 2009 https://vancouversun.com/opinion/STIR+step+right+direction/2373405/story.html</ref> homelessness and economic development<ref>Stephanie Levitz, Hope and despair in Vancouver's Eastside, ''The Canadian Press, CTV'', Monday December 28, 2009 http://www.ctvolympics.ca/news-centre/newsid=23996.html</ref> and industry clustering<ref>Clustering in Action, Robert Matas, ''Globe and Mail'', December 18, 2009 http://v1.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/RTGAM.20091218.escenic_1406276/BNStory/National/</ref> Though becoming more widely recognized in 2008 and 2009 the organization has struggled to overcome obscurity concerning its past and present work.
Directly related to its support of clustering in Vancouver's inner-city, BOB has also been noted for its co-working space<ref>{{cite web|last=Shaw |first=Gillian |url=http://communities.canada.com/vancouversun/blogs/techsense/archive/2009/12/18/vancouver-s-downtown-eastside-gets-innovative-cowork-space.aspx |title=Vancouver's Downtown Eastside gets innovative coworking space - Digital Life |publisher=Communities.canada.com |date=2009-12-18 |accessdate=2010-07-26}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last=Shaw |first=Gillian |url=https://vancouversun.com/shared+workspace+opens+Vancouver+inner+city/2366408/story.html |title=New shared workspace opens in Vancouver's inner city |publisher=Vancouversun.com |date=2009-12-21 |accessdate=2010-07-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100531062700/http://www.vancouversun.com/shared%2Bworkspace%2Bopens%2BVancouver%2Binner%2Bcity/2366408/story.html |archivedate=May 31, 2010 |df= }}</ref> made available for bloggers, independent media/social media, as well as independent contractors and consultants working in Vancouver's DTES.(Downtown Eastside) The BOB co-working space is also utilized as an art gallery and presentation space and is an official host gallery of the 2010 Winter Olympics' Cultural Olympiad.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vancouver2010.com/more-2010-information/cultural-festivals-and-events/event-listings/trimpin--sheng-high_131960nR.html |title=Trimpin: Sheng High - Event Listings : Vancouver 2010 Winter Olympics |publisher=Vancouver2010.com |date= |accessdate=2010-07-26}}</ref> The organization has also been noted for placing focus on social enterprise in the inner-city and was instrumental in the support and creation of the SOLEFood Inner City Farm Project along with Seann Dory of United We Can, and local property owners Gudy and Pal Sahota.<ref name="kelowna">{{cite web|url=http://www.kelowna.com/2009/10/31/new-community-garden-takes-root-in-the-downtown-eastside/|title=Kelowna News, Weather, Business, Sports, Entertainment, Classifieds, Real Estate & More | Kelowna.com|publisher=kelowna.com|accessdate=2014-02-05}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Christabel Shaler |url=http://www.vancouverobserver.com/blogs/comfortvschange/2009/11/01/solefood-inner-city-farm-source-food-and-jobs-vancouvers-dowtown |title=SOLEfood Inner City Farm: A Source of Food and Jobs for Vancouver's Dowtown Eastside | The Vancouver Observer - News, Culture, Sports, Blogs in Vancouver, BC |publisher=The Vancouver Observer |date=2009-11-01 |accessdate=2010-07-26}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www2.canada.com/vancouvercourier/news/story.html?id=85e2e05a-d62c-4f0a-8ecd-f7071f9a045d |title=Sitemap - Vancouver Courier |publisher=.canada.com |date= |accessdate=2010-07-26}}</ref>
==BOB and the Millennium CBA (Vancouver 2010 Olympic Village)==
BOB was involved in the creation of Vancouver's first [[Community Benefits Agreement]] centred on the construction of the Vancouver 2010 Olympic Village.<ref name="vancouver1">{{cite web |url=http://vancouver.ca/olympicvillage/pdf/CBAFactsheet.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-01-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120328052745/http://vancouver.ca/olympicvillage/PDF/CBAFactsheet.pdf |archivedate=2012-03-28 |df= }}</ref> While this development has been criticized for going over-budget<ref>Olympic village $130 million over budget: audit, Miro Cernetig,''Vancouver Sun'', October 6, 2009 https://vancouversun.com/business/Vancouver+Olympic+Village+million+over+budget+report/2072466/story.html</ref> the CBA may potentially serve as a valuable example of the emerging potential between investors, developers and social enterprise in urban planning. The CBA was a collective effort between the City of Vancouver, BOB, [[Vancouver Organizing Committee for the 2010 Olympic and Paralympic Winter Games|VANOC]] and Millennium Development Corporation focusing on job creation for local residents and encouraging direct procurement of goods and services from the Downtown Eastside as per the needs of the Olympic Village development.<ref name="vancouver1"/> Other major partners included Bell, [[VanCity Credit Union]], the [[Province of British Columbia]] and the Federal Government (as represented through the Vancouver agreement)as well as the Canadian Housing and Mortgage Corporation and the Vancouver Regional Construction Association.
==Criticism of BOB==
BOB has been the recipient of criticism from both activists who view the organization as a potential agent of gentrification and from other individuals active in the DTES. The organization has made efforts to clarify its role in the DTES in response to these criticisms.<ref name="canada1">{{cite web|url=http://www2.canada.com/vancouvercourier/news/story.html?id=eecc5d8e-977f-43d6-b31b-1b406fc20f9d |title=Sitemap - Vancouver Courier |publisher=.canada.com |date= |accessdate=2010-07-26}}</ref> PEACH (Partners for Economic and Community Health) having been proven largely ineffective in its approach was dismantled and its funding halted. BOB, though supporting a different development model and with different roles has also been viewed by some in Vancouver's DTES as not serving its primary purpose or being effective enough in job creation.<ref name="canada2">{{cite web|url=http://www2.canada.com/vancouvercourier/news/story.html?id=cda5b861-4837-487f-b5da-852f4d282cca |title=Sitemap - Vancouver Courier |publisher=.canada.com |date= |accessdate=2010-07-26}}</ref> Kim Kerr, executive director for the [[Downtown Eastside Residents Association]] and Vancouver employment councilor Ruth Meta are examples of vocal critics.<ref name="canada1"/><ref name="canada2"/> Meta and BOB CEO Shirley Chan both commented on BOB's role and work in the DTES through a series of articles in the Vancouver Courier in 2009<ref name="canada1"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www2.canada.com/vancouvercourier/news/letters/story.html?id=87989020-6e69-4926-b944-cf4a0bdef158 |title=Sitemap - Vancouver Courier |publisher=.canada.com |date= |accessdate=2010-07-26}}</ref> It is rumored that Meta reconciled with BOB after this exchange.
==References==
<references/> [[Community Benefits Agreement]] [external links] [https://web.archive.org/web/20120328052745/http://vancouver.ca/olympicvillage/PDF/CBAFactsheet.pdf]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Building Opportunities With Business}} [[Category:Business organizations based in Canada]] [[Category:Non-profit organizations based in Vancouver]]

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=December 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2012}} [[Image:CamelRacingCamelCup2009Heat.JPG|thumb|right|Camel racing during the 2009 [[Camel Cup]] held in [[Alice Springs]]]] [[File:Camel Race Track Qatar.jpg|thumb|right|[[Al-Shahaniya]], Qatar's largest camel racing track]] [[File:Dubai camel race.jpg|thumb|right|Camel racing in Dubai]] '''Camel racing''' is a popular sport in Pakistan, Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Bahrain, Jordan, Qatar, United Arab Emirates, Oman, Australia, and Mongolia. Professional camel racing, like [[horse racing]], is an event for [[betting]] and tourist attraction. [[Camel]]s can run at speeds up to 65 km/h (18 m/s; 40 mph) in short sprints and they can maintain a speed of 40 km/h (11 m/s; 25 mph) for an hour. Camels are often controlled by child jockeys, but allegations of human rights abuses have led to nationwide bans on underage labor in the [[UAE]] and [[Qatar]]. In modern camel racing, camels are often controlled by [[Robot jockey|remote controlled robotic whips]].
A major camel race is the [[Camel Cup]] held at [[Alice Springs, Northern Territory|Alice Springs]] which is the second biggest prize purse camel race in Australia. It is held annually and includes not only the camel races themselves, but also a collection of market stalls and other entertainment.
The biggest [[prize money]] camel race in Australia is "The Boulia desert Sands" with a A$25,000 prize purse in Queensland.
==Child jockeys== Children are often favored as jockeys because of their light weight. It has been reported that thousands of children (some reported as young as 2 years old) are [[human trafficking|trafficked]] from countries such as Afghanistan, Bangladesh, Iran, Pakistan,India and Sudan for use as jockeys for camel racing industry in [[Arab States of the Persian Gulf]].<ref>[https://www.state.gov/g/tip/rls/tiprpt/2005/46606.htm 2005 U.S. State Department Trafficking in Persons Report]. State.gov. Retrieved 2011-10-25.</ref> Estimates range of 5,000 – 40,000 child camel jockeys in the Persian Gulf region.<ref name="autogenerated1">Williamson, Lucy. (2005-02-04) [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/4236123.stm South Asia | Child camel jockeys find hope]. BBC News. Retrieved 2011-10-25.</ref><ref>[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/article438324.ece The Times | UK News, World News and Opinion]. Timesonline.co.uk. Retrieved 2011-10-25.</ref>
Many child camel jockeys are seriously injured by falling off the camels.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/4063391.stm Middle East | Help for Gulf child camel jockeys]. BBC News (2004-12-02). Retrieved 2011-10-25.</ref> The child jockeys live in camps (called "ousbah") near the racetracks and many are victims of abuse.<ref name="autogenerated1"/> Hundreds of children have been rescued from camel farms in Oman, Qatar, and [[UAE]] and taken back to their original homes or kept in shelter homes.<ref>[http://gulfnews.com/news/gulf/uae/general/under-age-camel-jockeys-get-caring-hand-1.106700 Under-age camel jockeys get caring hand]. gulfnews. Retrieved 2011-10-25.</ref> Many however, are unable to identify their parents or home communities in South Asia or Sudan. Some countries have issued penalties for those who trafficked child camel jockeys and ordered the owners responsibilities for returning the children back to their home countries. However, they report that in many instances the children rescued were those who had been sold away by their own parents in exchange for money or a job abroad. If they were returned, the children would again be sold for the same purposes. Other children did not speak their native languages, or did not know how to live outside the camel farms.
A prominent activist for rehabilitation and recovery of the jockeys is Pakistani lawyer [[Ansar Burney]]. He has focused a portion of his work on eliminating the use of child jockeys.
===Banning=== The United Arab Emirates was the first to ban the use of children under 15 as jockeys in camel racing when [[Sheikh]] [[Hamdan bin Zayed bin Sultan Al Nahyan|Hamdan bin Zayed Al Nahyan]] announced the ban on 29 July 2002.<ref>[http://www.khaleejtimes.com/DisplayArticle.asp?xfile=data/theuae/2005/May/theuae_May691.xml&section=theuae UAE enforces stringent steps to eradicate child jockeys] (Wam), ''[[Khaleej Times]]'', 24 May 2005</ref> In 2009 the UAE paid compensation to 879 former jockeys.<ref>Nelson, Dean. (2009-05-05) [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/bangladesh/5278605/Former-camel-jockeys-compensated-by-UAE.html Former camel jockeys compensated by UAE]. Telegraph. Retrieved 2012-01-27.</ref> The UAE now issues penalties such as jail and banning for those found using children as jockeys. In 2010, volunteers from Anti-Slavery International photographed violations of this ban.<ref>Peachey, Paul. (2010-03-03) [https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/uae-defies-ban-on-child-camel-jockeys-1914915.html UAE defies ban on child camel jockeys – Middle East – World]. The Independent. Retrieved 2012-01-27.</ref>
In Qatar, the [[Emir of Qatar]], [[Hamad bin Khalifa Al Thani|Hamad Al Thani]], banned child jockeys in 2005<ref name=GUK>[https://www.theguardian.com/life/thisweek/story/0,12977,1458529,00.html Can robots ride camels?] by Ian Sample, ''[[The Guardian]]'', Thursday, 2005-04-14</ref> and directed that, by 2007, all camel races would be directed by [[robot jockey|robotic jockey]]s.<ref name=Wired>[https://www.wired.com/wired/archive/13.11/camel.html?pg=1&topic=camel&topic_set= "Robots of Arabia"] by Jim Lewis, ''[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]'', Issue 13.11, November 2005.</ref>
==See also== *[[Desert racing]] *[[Camel wrestling]] *[[The Great Australian Camel Race]], an Australian event held in 1988 to recognize the positive impact that camels had on the development of Australia
==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}}
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20081020030737/http://camelraces.net/ camelraces.net]- Arabic * [https://web.archive.org/web/20051025042252/http://www.zipzak.com/ Information and Resource Guide to Camel Racing] * [http://www.omanholiday.co.uk/Day-at-the-Races-by-Tony-Walsh-for-Arab-News.pdf Traditional Camel Racing in Oman article] * [http://www.saudiaramcoworld.com/issue/200103/racing.in.rhythm.in.the.uae.htm Racing in Rhythm in the UAE] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080611135303/http://www.uae.gov.ae/Government/sports.htm UAE Sports] * [https://www.jstor.org/pss/3774109 JSTOR] * [http://www.forbes-nsw.com/CamelRacesForbes.html Camel racing in Forbes NSW Australia - Pics & vid.]
{{Racing}}
[[Category:Animal racing]] [[Category:Camels]] [[Category:Child labour]] [[Category:Sport in the Arab world]] [[Category:Sport in Asia]]

page.title: Cannes Lions International Festival of Creativity

revision.text:
{{advert|date=January 2017}} The '''Cannes Lions International Festival of Creativity''' (formerly the '''International Advertising Festival''')<ref>{{cite web|title=2011 Cannes Lions: From Advertising to Creativity|url=http://thehitboard.com/2011/06/27/2011-cannes-lions-from-advertising-to-creativity/}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=2011 Cannes Lions 2011 Review|url=http://www.brandify.co.uk/unbranded/canneslions2011/}}</ref> is a global event for those working in creative communications, advertising, and related fields. It is considered the largest gathering of the advertising and creative communications industry.<ref>{{cite news|title=World's biggest ad festival to kick off in Cannes|url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2010-06-09/news/27583196_1_cannes-lions-entries-promo-activation | work=The Times Of India | date=9 June 2010}}</ref>
The five-day festival, incorporating the awarding of the Lions awards, is held yearly at the [[Palais des Festivals et des Congrès]] in [[Cannes]], [[France]].<ref>[http://www.canneslions.com/about/news.cfm?newsid=87 News | About Us | Cannes Lions International Festival of Creativity] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111011133249/http://www.canneslions.com/about/news.cfm?newsid=87 |date=October 11, 2011 }}</ref> Each June, around 11,000 registered delegates from 90 countries visit the Festival to celebrate the best of creativity in brand communication, discuss industry issues, and network with one another.<ref name=autogenerated2>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/jun/20/cannes-festival-rebrands-digital-age?INTCMP=SRCH | location=London | work=The Guardian | first=Mark | last=Sweney | title=Cannes advertising festival rebrands to reflect digital age | date=20 June 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2010/jun/22/cannes-lions-martin-sorrell-wpp | location=London | work=The Guardian | first=Mark | last=Sweney | title=Sir Martin Sorrell: Cannes Lions is 'a chance to get away' | date=22 June 2010}}</ref> The week's activities include multiple award ceremonies as well as an opening and closing gala.<ref>http://www.canneslions.com/festival/whats_on.cfm {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111011131757/http://www.canneslions.com/festival/whats_on.cfm |date=October 11, 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/Business/Business-News/2013/06/08/Cannes-Lions-attracts-record-number-of-entries.aspx |title=Cannes Lions attracts record number of entries - Business News | The Star Online |publisher=Thestar.com.my |date=2013-06-08 |accessdate=2014-02-05}}</ref>
==History== Inspired by the [[Cannes Film Festival]], staged in Cannes since the late 1940s, a group of cinema screen advertising contractors belonging to the Screen Advertising World Association (Sawa) felt the makers of advertising films should be similarly recognised. They established the International Advertising Film Festival, the first of which took place in [[Venice]], [[Italy]], in September 1954, with 187 film entries from 14 countries. The lion of the [[Piazza San Marco]] in Venice was the inspiration for the Lion trophy.<ref>{{cite web|title=The History of Advertising 20 - A Cannes Lion|url=http://www.campaignlive.co.uk/analysis/1076691/}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Tungate|first1=Mark|title=Adland: A Global History of Advertising|url=https://books.google.co.in/books?id=7J3JeXJ7ITgC&pg=PA229&lpg=PA229&dq=cannes+lion+winged&source=bl&ots=A0HHyP_M2J&sig=Jw9vlTi8gGN042Fo1rOXLsbr8RM&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwic2JOmiIfYAhWs1IMKHfGrD1U4ChDoAQg2MAQ#v=onepage&q=cannes%20lion%20winged&f=false}}</ref>
The second festival was held in [[Monte Carlo]], and the third in Cannes. After that, the event alternated between Venice and Cannes before settling in the latter in 1984.<ref name=autogenerated1>[http://www.adweek.com/cannes-lions-2011/history-cannes-lions-ad-films-carnival-creativity-132774 ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110822164555/http://www.adweek.com/cannes-lions-2011/history-cannes-lions-ad-films-carnival-creativity-132774 |date=August 22, 2011 }}</ref> New categories have been awards in recent years: the Press & Outdoor Lions competition in 1992; the Cyber Lions in 1998 (retired after 2017); Media Lions in 1999; Direct Lions in 2002; Radio, and Titanium Lions in 2005; Promo & Activation Lions in 2006 (retired after 2017); Design Lions in 2008; PR Lions in 2009; Film Craft in 2010; Creative Effectiveness in 2011;<ref name=autogenerated1 /> Branded Content & Entertainment and Mobile Lions in 2012; Innovation in 2013 and Creative eCommerce and Social & Influencer in 2018. However, in recent years, there have been calls from within the industry for the Festival to simplify the entry categories to better reflect the current state of the modern communications world.<ref name=autogenerated3>{{cite web |url=http://creativity-online.com/news/categories-schmategories/228440 |title=Categories, Schmategories - Cannes 2011 |publisher=Creativity Online |date=2011-06-27 |accessdate=2014-02-05 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140213094147/http://creativity-online.com/news/categories-schmategories/228440 |archive-date=2014-02-13 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> The festival responded by introducing changes in 2018, including new categories, revising costs and reducing the event from seven days to five.
In the 1990s, the Festival also added a programme of learning in the form of seminars and workshops.<ref name=autogenerated1 /> Over the years, this side of the Festival has grown considerably, and in 2013 it featured around 130 sessions over 7 days.<ref>[http://www.canneslions.com/the_festival/programme/festival_programme.cfm The Festival | Cannes Lions International Festival of Creativity] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130914214933/http://www.canneslions.com/the_festival/programme/festival_programme.cfm |date=2013-09-14 }}[http://www.canneslions.com/festival/full_schedule.cfm?filter=1,2,3 <!-- Bot generated title -->]{{dead link|date=September 2018|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> These included talks from [[Christopher Bailey (fashion designer)|Christopher Bailey]], [[Jack Black]], [[Jenson Button]], [[Nick Cannon]], [[Shepard Fairey]], [[Arianna Huffington]], [[David Karp]], and [[Annie Leibovitz]].
In 2004, British publisher and conference organiser EMAP plc (now called [[Ascential]]) purchased the festival from French businessman [[Roger Hatchuel]] - who had started managing it in 1987 - for a reported [[pound sterling|£]]52 million.<ref>{{cite news|title=Emap buys Cannes advertising festival|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2004/aug/10/emap.advertising | location=London | work=The Guardian|first1=Phil|last1=Sommerich|first2=Jane|last2=Martinson|date=10 August 2004}}</ref> In June 2014, the ''Wall Street Journal''<ref>Jack Marshall, [https://blogs.wsj.com/cmo/2014/06/18/ad-agency-spoofs-cannes-for-promo-videos/ "Ad Agency Spoofs Cannes for Promo Videos featuring Nimrod Kamer"], Wall Street Journal, June 18, 2014</ref> as well as ''Campaign Magazine''<ref>Ben Hall, [http://www.campaignlive.co.uk/news/1299546/Watch-Satirist-takes-Sir-Martin-Sorrell-joins-Kanye-Wests-entourage/ "Watch: Satirist takes on Sir Martin Sorrell and joins Kanye West's entourage"], Campaign Magazine, June 19, 2014</ref> reported on [[Nimrod Kamer]]'s protestations at Cannes Lions.
Jose Papa is the managing director. Philip Thomas is chairman and the chief executive officer of Ascential Events, under which Cannes Lions operates.<ref>{{cite web |title=Cannes Lions appoints new CEO |url=http://www.bandt.com.au/news/cannes-lions-appoints-new-ceo |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20121230081940/http://www.bandt.com.au/news/cannes-lions-appoints-new-ceo |archivedate=2012-12-30 |df= }}</ref>
==The Awards==
Cannes Lions juries are drawn from experts in each field from around the world. Each jury is headed by a jury president. They judge submissions in Film, Film Craft, Industry Craft, Digital Craft, Media, Print & Publishing, Outdoor, Direct, Pharma, Health & Wellness, Design, Radio & Audio, Mobile, Branded Content & Entertainment, Brand Experience & Activation, Creative eCommerce, Entertainment, Entertainment Lions for Music, PR, Creative Effectiveness, Social & Influencer, Creative Data, Innovation and Titanium, as well as Glass: The Lion for Change and Sustainable Development Goals. In 2013, the Festival launched a new category called the Innovation Lions, which are supposed to "honour the technology and innovation which facilitates creativity",<ref>{{cite web|last=Pathak |first=Shareen |url=http://adage.com/article/agency-news/cannes-advertising-fest-intros-innovation-lion-award/239219/ |title=Cannes Advertising Fest Intros 'Innovation Lion' Award | Agency News - Advertising Age |publisher=Adage.com |date=2013-01-16 |accessdate=2014-02-05}}</ref> including recognition of the 'Top 10 Startups to Watch'.<ref>{{cite web|title=Elizabeth Aris - CEO and Co-Founder of MOSH.|url=http://thenativesociety.com/tnspeak/elizabeth-aris-ceo-co-founder-of-mosh.html|website=The Native Society|accessdate=28 April 2016}}</ref> Additionally, global start-ups can apply for the Start-up Academy to receive festival passes and access mentorship sessions.<ref>{{cite web|title=Start-up Academy Finalists Announced|url=https://www.canneslions.com/press/press_releases/1100/start_up_academy_finalists_announced|website=Canne Lions International Festival of Creativity|accessdate=1 June 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160423101842/http://www.canneslions.com/press/press_releases/1100/start_up_academy_finalists_announced/|archivedate=23 April 2016|df=}}</ref>
Other awards include Holding Company of the Year, Network of the Year, Media Agency of the Year, Agency of the Year, Independent Agency of the Year, Media Person of the Year, [[New Directors' Showcase]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://saatchi.com/en-in/new-directors-showcase/new-directors-showcase-years/ |title=New Directors' Showcase |publisher=Saatchi & Saatchi Global}}</ref> Advertiser of the Year, and the Palme d'Or to the best production company.<ref>[http://www.canneslions.com/enter/rules_fees.cfm?section_id=59 Enter the Awards | Cannes Lions International Festival of Creativity] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111112085001/http://www.canneslions.com/enter/rules_fees.cfm?section_id=59 |date=November 12, 2011 }}</ref>
Advertisements are generally entered by the agencies that created them, although technically anyone can enter any advertising creation, providing it ran within a specified time frame. The jurors are instructed to reward advertising that is deemed most creative both in idea and execution.
In an article in ''The Guardian'' in 2009, WPP boss Sir [[Martin Sorrell]] said the Cannes Lions awards were too costly to enter.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2009/jul/07/sir-martin-sorrell-cannes-lions-cost-wpp | location=London | work=The Guardian | first=Mark | last=Sweney | title=Sir Martin Sorrell criticises Cannes Lions on cost and new category | date=7 July 2009}}</ref> However, a year later, he also admitted that he had made sure that WPP was "very, very focused on Cannes" and wanted to be "the leader in terms of awards at Cannes".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://blogs.hillandknowlton.com/cannes/tv/ |title=Cannes Eye TV › Cannes Eye |publisher=Blogs.hillandknowlton.com |date= |accessdate=2014-02-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222220602/http://blogs.hillandknowlton.com/cannes/tv/ |archivedate=2014-02-22 |df= }}</ref> In 2011, WPP won the first Holding Company of the Year prize at the Festival.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.shots.net/news/awards-festivals-events/70330/nike-writes-itself-into-history.html |title=Cannes Lions 2011: Nike Writes Itself into History, Awards, Festivals & Events, News |publisher=Shots.net |date=2011-06-26 |accessdate=2014-02-05}}</ref> Commenting on this industry recognition, WPP Worldwide Creative Director, John O'Keeffe, said:
"Cannes is the only global, cross discipline show, covering advertising, design, digital, media, promo, effectiveness, and everything else besides. It doesn't aggregate the scores of other shows, so you can't inflate your ranking on the back of just one or two pieces of work. If you are number one at Cannes, you've done it the hard way, the proper way, the only way."<ref>[http://www.wpp.com/wpp/press/press/default.htm?guid={3765e5b6-0ec4-478b-8b4b-24f9b2ab00f4} WPP most creatively-awarded global group in Cannes - WPP] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120630010245/http://www.wpp.com/wpp/press/press/default.htm?guid= |date=June 30, 2012 }}</ref>
In 2013, the "[[Dumb Ways to Die]]" a campaign by [[McCann Australia]] for Australian company [[Metro Trains]] made history by winning a total of five Grands Prix awards, the most ever awarded to a single piece of work.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/06/24/us-australia-advertising-die-idUSBRE95N03L20130624 |title=Quirky 'Dumb Ways to Die' campaign sweeps advertising awards |publisher=Reuters |date= 2013-06-24|accessdate=2014-02-05}}</ref>
The [[Lion of St. Mark (award)|Lion of St. Mark]] is an honour given each year at the [[Cannes Lions]] International Festival of Creativity to "someone who has made outstanding contributions to the creative community."
==Young Lions Competitions== [[File:Cannes Young Lions Competition Gold Medal.jpg|right|thumb|280px|Cannes Young Lions Competition Gold Medal]] The Young Lions Competitions (previously known as the Young Creatives competition, which started in 1995) is open to advertising professionals up to 28 years old working in teams of two. The competition takes place during the festival week in Cannes in seven divisions: print, cyber, film, design, young marketers, media, and PR. Regional competitions are held in most countries<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.canneslions.com/resources/downloads/Reps%20Competition%20List%202016.pdf|title=Young Lions Competitions|author=|date=|website=canneslions.com|accessdate=7 April 2018}}</ref> to select teams in the lead-up to the Festival, with winners of these going into the final round of the competitions at Cannes Lions.<ref>[https://www.canneslions.com/school/Competitions/ "YOUNG LIONS COMPETITIONS: How to take part"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160502185136/http://www.canneslions.com/school/Competitions |date=2016-05-02 }}, canneslions.com</ref> A design competition was launched in 2012.<ref>[http://www.canneslions.com/talent_training/competitions.cfm ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131001152644/http://www.canneslions.com/talent_training/competitions.cfm |date=October 1, 2013 }}</ref>
==Lions Health== In June 2012, Cannes Lions announced that it plans to launch a new two-day event for creative communications in healthcare, wellness, and sustainability. Taking place in the Palais des Festivals in Cannes, France, just before Cannes Lions kicks off on 15 June 2014, the event will offer two days of content that will explore and debate the essential and unique issues relating to the world of healthcare communications. The move was welcomed by some sections of the industry, with Jeremy Perrott, global creative director of [[McCann Erickson|McCann]] Health, commenting: "Lions Health gives the industry the highest stage to showcase its brilliance."<ref>{{cite web|last=Wentz |first=Laurel |url=http://adage.com/article/global-news/cannes-add-lions-health-2014-separate-festival/242071/ |title=Cannes Will Add Lions Health in 2014 In Separate Festival | Global News - Advertising Age |publisher=Adage.com |date=2013-06-12 |accessdate=2014-02-05}}</ref> In 2017 Lions Health was moved to take place at the same time as the main festival, but remains a standalone event in another part of the Palais.[https://www.prweek.com/article/1450473/lions-health-remain-separate-cannes-revamp]
==References== {{reflist|2}}

[[File:Carlos Casado del Alisal, Rosario.jpg|thumb|Monument to Carlos Casado del Alisal, by sculptor [[Eduardo Barnes]]]]
'''Carlos Casado del Alisal''' (March 16, 1833 — June 29, 1899) was a [[Spanish Argentine]] businessman.
==Life and times==
Carlos Casado del Alisal was born in [[Villada]], [[Palencia Province]], [[Spain]]. He arrived in [[Santa Fe Province]], [[Argentina]] in 1857, and in 1864, was named to the Board of Directors of the newly established [[Central Argentine Railway]] by its chief stockholder, [[William Wheelwright]]. Serving in the [[Rosario]] City Council, he also established the Casado Bank in 1865, and ''Colonia Candelaria'', an [[Agricultural colonies in Argentina|agricultural colony]], in 1870; the latter was later reestablished as [[Casilda]], in honor of his mother. He founded the [[New Bank of Santa Fe|Provincial Bank of Santa Fe]] in 1874, and purchased the highly indebted ''Colonia Caridad'' in 1878, redeveloping it as San Genaro (in honor of his daughter's [[patron saint]], [[Saint Gennaro]]).<ref>[http://www.casildavirtual.com.ar/historia1.php Carlos Casado y la historia de la ciudad de Casilda] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722012346/http://www.casildavirtual.com.ar/historia1.php |date=July 22, 2011 }} {{es icon}}</ref>
Casado arranged the first shipment of Argentine [[wheat]] to [[Europe]] in 1878; the 4,500 tons of wheat had been grown in Candelaria, and were shipped on April 12, 1878.<ref>[http://www.lbosa.com.ar/lbosa/granos/notas.vsp?nid=4138 La primera exportación de trigo argentino] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706081703/http://www.lbosa.com.ar/lbosa/granos/notas.vsp?nid=4138 |date=July 6, 2011 }} {{es icon}}</ref> He was subsequently named [[monetary policy]] adviser by President [[Nicolás Avellaneda]], and helped direct national support toward the export of cereal at a time when [[leather]] and [[dried meat]]s earned most of the nation's [[Foreign exchange reserves|foreign exchange]].<ref name=scarecrow>''Historical Dictionary of Argentina''. London: Scarecrow Press, 1978.</ref> President of the Bank of Santa Fe, he also sat on the boards of the [[Bank of the Province of Buenos Aires]] and the [[Banco Hipotecario|Mortgage Bank]] as the representative for Santa Fe Province stockholders from 1882. Casado founded the [[Santa Fe Western Railway]] in 1883, and the rail line would, by 1890, connect much of the agriculturally-rich province to the [[Port of Rosario]] and the [[Paraná River]].<ref>[http://www.bancobsf.com.ar/institucional_historia.asp Nuevo Banco de Santa Fe. ''Historia institucional''] {{es icon}}</ref>
Following the [[Paraguayan War]], in which Argentina annexed what became [[Formosa Province]] from [[Paraguay]], Casado became of the new province's leading landowners. He died in [[Buenos Aires]] in 1899, at age 66.<ref name=scarecrow/>
Carlos Casado del Alisal was honored with a monument sculpted by [[Eduardo Barnes]], and unveiled at the Rosario headquarters of the Provincial Bank of Santa Fe in 1970.
His brother was the well-known Spanish painter [[José Casado del Alisal]].
