{{Infobox person | name = Dalton Philips | image = | caption = | birth_name = Timothy David Dalton Philips | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1968|02|18}} | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | residence = | nationality = Irish | ethnicity = | education = [[Stowe School]] | alma_mater = [[University College Dublin]]
[[Harvard University]] | occupation = Businessman | years_active = 1989–present | salary = | title = Leaving Chief Executive of [[Morrisons]] plc | term = 2010– Until March 2015 | predecessor = [[Marc Bolland]] | successor = [[David Potts (businessman)|David Potts]] | spouse = | children = }} '''Timothy David Dalton Philips''' (born 18 February 1968) is an Irish businessman. He was the CEO of the UK supermarket chain [[Morrisons]] from January 2010 until March 2015, when he was succeeded by [[David Potts (businessman)|David Potts]]. He is currently Chairman of [[Byron Hamburgers]] and Chairman of timber and building merchant The Ridgeon Group, as well as holding a number of advisory and non-executive positions. ==Early life== Born in Ireland, Philips is the son of a [[County Wicklow]] poultry farmer. He has a BA from University College Dublin, a MBA from Harvard Business School and an honorary Doctorate of Management from Bradford University. ==Career== His retailing career began in New Zealand, where he began as a store manager. He then had 11 jobs in 14 countries, including an appointment to [[Jardine Matheson]]'s [[Dairy Farm International Holdings|Dairy Farm International]]. He joined [[Walmart]] in 1998, and after working in Brazil, rose to the position of [[Chief Operating Officer]] in Germany. He then joined the [[Weston family]] retail operation as CEO of upmarket Irish department store group [[Brown Thomas]] in 2007, and then becoming Chief Operating Officer of Canadian retailer [[Loblaw]] in January 2007, under [[Allan Leighton]]. After Morrisons CEO [[Marc Bolland]] announced his departure to [[Marks and Spencers]] in December 2009, Philips was appointed in a surprise move as his replacement in January 2010.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/8483863.stm|title=Morrisons names Dalton Philips as new chief executive|publisher=BBC News|date=2010-01-28|accessdate=2010-01-28}} However, Leighton worked with Morrisons chairman Sir Ian Gibson during his tenure at [[Asda]], and is good friends with founder [[Ken Morrison|Sir Ken Morrison]].{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2010/jan/27/morrisons-new-chief|title=Morrisons appoints Irishman Dalton Philips as new chief executive|publisher=The Guardian|date=2010-01-28|accessdate=2010-01-28 | location=London | first=Zoe | last=Wood}}{{cite news|url=http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/industry_sectors/retailing/article7005426.ece|title=Morrisons names its new chief but keeps Bolland waiting at the checkout|publisher=The Times|date=2010-01-28|accessdate=2010-01-28 | location=London | first1=Marcus | last1=Leroux | first2=Ian | last2=King}} At Morrisons annual AGM in June 2014, Morrisons former chairman Sir [[Ken Morrison]] blasted Phillips and his new board of directors for their running of the company Morrison inherited from his father. Morrison's comments were backed up by his nephew Chris Blundell, who controls most of the remaining family stake in the supermarket, also told the board it needed rescuing, and welcomed the decision by chairman Sir Ian Gibson to leave the business next year after months of pressure.{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/news/veteran-morrisons-founder-hits-out-at-the-board-your-strategy-is-a-load-of-bull-9497648.html|title=Sir Ken Blasts Morrisons CEO, Chairman and the board of directors|publisher=The Independent|date=2014-06-06|accessdate=2014-06-06}} In January 2015 it was announced that Philips would be stepping down as CEO.{{cite news|url=http://dailybusinessgroup.co.uk/2015/01/poor-sales-put-future-of-morrisons-boss-philips-in-doubt/?|title=Philips pays the price for Morrisons' slump in sales|publisher=dailybusinessgroup|date=2015-01-13|accessdate=2015-01-13}} Philips, as well as being chairman of Byron, and of The Ridgeon Group, is currently a Senior Advisor with The [[Boston Consulting Group]], and is a Non-Executive Director of three other boards: industrial plastic group One51 Plc., the UK High Street retailer [[Wilko (retailer)|Wilko]], and the Social Innovation Fund, a provider of growth capital to Irish social enterprises. ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Philips, Dalton}} [[Category:1968 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from County Wicklow]] [[Category:People educated at Stowe School]] [[Category:Alumni of University College Dublin]] [[Category:Harvard Business School alumni]] [[Category:Irish businesspeople]] [[Category:Walmart people]] [[Category:Chief operating officers]]

{{Multiple issues| {{Orphan|date=June 2013}} {{BLP sources|date=December 2015}} }} {{Use British English|date=May 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2013}} {{Infobox person |bodystyle= |name = Etsko Schuitema |image = Etsko Schuitema mugshot.jpg |caption = Schuitema in 2010 |headerstyle = background:#e78f05; |labelstyle = background:#f6a51f; |birth_name = Etsko Odilus Franciscus Schuitema |birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1959|04|07}} |birth_place = [[Klerksdorp]], South Africa |occupation = [[Entrepreneur|Founder]], [[Partnership|Leading Partner]], Author, Entrepreneur, [[Sufi]] |alma_mater = [[University of Witwatersrand]] (1977–1980) |education = BA Social Anthropology (Honors) (1980) | residence = [[Johannesburg]], South Africa |spouse = |children = Khalil Shuitema (born 1987)
Assad Schuitema (born 1990)
Muhammad Schuitema (born 1994)
Salima Omland (born 2000) | awards = [[Military Merit Medal (South Africa)|Chief of the South African Defense Force Commendation Medal]] |website = Official Schuitema blog
[http://www.schuitema.co.za/ Schuitema Associates Website] }} '''Etsko Schuitema''' (born 7 April 1959), is the founder and [[Partnership|Leading Partner]] of Schuitema Associates, a [[business transformation]] consultancy that is based in South Africa and Pakistan. An [[anthropologist]] by training, Etsko developed the Care and Growth Leadership Model{{cite news|last=Ahmed|first=Adil|title=Developing Human Capital|url=http://archives.dawn.com/weekly/review/archive/051117/review1.htm|newspaper=The Dawn|date=17 November 2005}} while he was employed with the [[South African Chamber of Mines]], which he left in 1989 to research and develop the framework further under Schuitema Associates. He is also a practicing Sufi {{citation needed|date=December 2015}} == Background and education == Etsko Schuitema was born to Jurjen and Johanna Schuitema in [[Klerksdorp]], a mining town in the North West province of South Africa. Both his parents were in the mining industry, and as such he had been exposed to the South African mining industry from a young age.{{cite web|last=Khan|first=Razia|title=Etsko Schuitema|url=http://www.dailytimes.com.pk/default.asp?page=2008%5C11%5C16%5Cstory_16-11-2008_pg15_2|publisher=Daily Times|accessdate=16 November 2008}} Etsko's elder brother is Jerry Schuitema, a South African journalist, author and retired management consultant.{{cite web|last=Moneyweb|first=ZA|title=The Human Touch|url=http://www.moneyweb.co.za/moneyweb-the-human-touch|work=Moneyweb.co.za}} In 1980, Schuitema completed an [[Honours degree]] in [[Social Anthropology]] from the [[University of Witwatersrand]], South Africa and in 1980 was subsequently employed by the Human Resources Laboratory of the [[South African Chamber of Mines]] as a researcher.{{cite book|last=Macleod|first=Guy|title=Cultural considerations : a guide to understanding culture, courtesy and etiquette in South African business|year=2002|publisher=Spearhead|location=Claremont|isbn=0864865317|pages=179, 180|edition=1st}} In 1984, he led the research team to perform research on employee discontent. == Career == === Period === The research was done during the peak of [[apartheid]] in South Africa. The [[gold mines]] were South Africa's biggest industry; with its workforce coming from all the ethnic tribes of the region{{cite web|title=South Africa's Mining History|url=http://info.goldavenue.com/info_site/in_mine/in_min_sa_his.htm|work=Gold Avenue|publisher=goldavenue.com}} and they reflected the problems that were plaguing South Africa during the apartheid regime.{{cite journal|last=Byrnes|first=Rita M.|title=ed. South Africa: A Country Study|journal=Ed. South Africa: A Country Study|year=1996|volume=Washington: GPO for the Library of Congress|series=South Africa|issue=Employment and Labor|url=http://countrystudies.us/south-africa/65.htm|accessdate=23 February 2013}} === Research === The Chamber of Mines Research Organisation commissioned Schuitema and his team to find out what was causing employee conflict in the mines at the organisation.{{cite news|last=Kumar|first=Shiva|title=Etsko Schuitema at work|url=http://gulfnews.com/life-style/people/etsko-schuitema-at-work-1.25684|accessdate=27 January 2012|newspaper=Gulf News|date=24 July 2008}} The survey instrument looked at variables that could account for employee discontent and mistrust towards the management. === Birth of Care and Growth Model & Schuitema Associates === What emerged from the research was that the variables and managerial behaviours that accounted for minimal work conflict, willingness at work, loyalty and trust towards the management were two: '''Care''' and '''Growth'''.{{cite journal|last=KRIEL|first=IGNATIUS GERHARDUS|title=DEVELOPMENTAL LEADERSHIP BEHAVIOUR AND AFFECTIVE COMMITMENT: AN EXPLORATIVE STUDY|date=November 2008|pages=21, 27, 119|url=http://uir.unisa.ac.za/bitstream/handle/10500/2695/thesis_kriel_%20g.pdf}}{{cite web|last=Hollander|first=Allen|title=Employee Engagement|url=http://hollanderleadershipblog.wordpress.com/2011/04/22/employee-engagement-2011/|publisher=Hollander Leadership Blog|accessdate=22 April 2011}} It was found that the employees who felt the management was genuinely interested in their welfare as individuals and professionals, trusted their immediate supervisors significantly more than the men who believed the management had no interest in this regard.{{cite journal|last=Illes|first=Katalin|author2=Jim Platts|title=Trust is a Process. A New Direction in Business Education|date=15 October 2006|pages=4–5|url=http://publications.eng.cam.ac.uk/325452/}} From his research on conflict and trust in management, Schuitema believes that power only becomes legitimate where the leader benevolently{{cite web|last=McCarthy|first=Debbie|title=Key elements to becoming a leader|url=http://tlcglobal.wordpress.com/2012/10/05/key-elements-to-becoming-a-leader/|publisher=Training Leadership Consulting|accessdate=5 October 2012}} exists to provide unconditional care, and fair and honest growth for his/her subordinates.{{cite web|last=Mabili|title=Transactional Leadership vs Transformational Leadership?|url=http://www.mabili.co.za/default.asp?pageid=2863|accessdate=2010}} Schuitema Associates was subsequently founded in January 1990 and the Care and Growth Leadership framework was further developed.{{cite web|last=Ramla|first=Akhtar|title=ETSKO SCHUITEMA: INTENT – CARE & GROWTH|url=http://www.tbl.com.pk/etsko-schuitema-intent-care-growth/|work=TBL – Triple Bottom-Line|publisher=TBL – Triple Bottom-Line|accessdate=27 January 2012}} Schuitema promotes the importance of leadership in empowering employees through genuine care and the creation of growth opportunities and empowerment.{{cite web|last=Gray|first=Mark|title=Lead with Care|url=http://www.graylink.biz/blog/lead-with-care-marklivescom-feature-article/|publisher=Graylink|accessdate=23 November 2008}} Schuitema gives lectures on the Care and Growth material on a regular basis at the [[Institute for Manufacturing]] at the [[University of Cambridge]]{{cite journal|last=Harris|first=Howard|author2=Katalin Illes|title=Promoting and Assessing Integrity in the Research Degree|journal=Electronic Journal of Business Ethics and Organization Studies|year=2008|volume=13|series=2|issue=9|page=58|url=http://ejbo.jyu.fi/pdf/ejbo_vol13_no2_pages_54-60.pdf}} and the [[Gordon Institute of Business Science]]{{cite web|last=GIBS|first=Programme|title=GIBS Programme|url=http://www.gibs.co.za/programmes/corporate-education-executive-programmes/short-courses/values-driven-leadership.aspx|work=Gordon Institute of Business Science|publisher=Gordon Institute of Business Science}} in South Africa. === Birth of Intent/Personal Excellence Model === While teaching the Care and Growth Leadership Model to business leaders and educators,{{cite journal|last=Science & Maths Schools|first=LEAP|title=LEAP 2011 Annual Report|year=2011|page=14|url=http://leapschool.org.za/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/LEAP_ANNUAL2011_Final.pdf}} Schuitema discovered that [[Learning organization#Characteristics|personal mastery]] and successful [[leadership]] of others are interlinked.{{cite web|last=Jordan|first=Bay|title=A picture of employee engagement and how to create it|url=http://blog.zealise.com/zealise_blog/2011/12/a-picture-of-employee-engagement-and-how-to-create-it-.html|publisher=Zealise|accessdate=6 December 2011}} Schuitema through his company Schuitema Associates also performs Personal Excellence courses. His clients for the Personal Excellence courses have included: * [[Fergus Blackie]], former Zimbabwe [[High Court]] [[Justice]] * [http://www.whoswho.co.za/michael-jordaan-3717 Dr. Michael Jordaan], chief executive officer of [[First National Bank (South Africa)|First National Bank]]{{cite web|last=Leader|first=SA|title=FNB CEO, Michael Jordaan: The Sin of Averaging {{!}} Leader.co.za|url=http://www.leader.co.za/event.aspx?s=3&f=1&ei=578|work=Leader ZA|publisher=Leader ZA}}{{cite web|title=Regenesys ZA|url=http://regenesys.co.za/2011/05/michael-jordaan/|work=Regenesys|publisher=Regenesys}} * [http://www.whoswho.co.za/robert-tucker-4381 Bob Tucker], former CEO of the [http://www.banking.org.za/ South African Banking Council] * [http://www.milescrisp.co.za Miles Crisp], former member of the [[Deloitte & Touche]] South African executive committee and founding partner of Anderson Rochussen Crisp{{cite web|title=SecureData Board of Directors|url=http://www.sdholdings.co.za/index.php/about-us/board-of-directors|work=SecureData}}{{cite web|last=Mawson|first=Nicola|title=SecureData appoints new CEO|url=http://www.itweb.co.za/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=57130|work=ITWeb|accessdate=23 February 2013}} * [http://www.whoswho.co.za/graham-edwards-1294 Dr Graham Edwards], chief executive of [[AECI Limited]]{{cite web|last=Roundup|first=Global Business|title=Dr. Graham Edwards: CEO, AECI|url=http://gbroundup.wordpress.com/2013/01/31/dr-graham-edwards-ceo-aeci/|work=Global Business Roundup|publisher=Global Business Roundup}} * [http://za.linkedin.com/pub/mark-munroe/4a/3b7/623 Mark Munroe], [[Executive Vice-President]] of [[Lonmin|Lonmin Platinum]]{{cite web|last=Reuters|first=PLC|title=People: Lonmin PLC (LMI.L)|url=https://www.reuters.com/finance/stocks/officerProfile?symbol=LMI.L&officerId=1426248|work=Reuters|publisher=Reuters}} * [http://za.linkedin.com/pub/fran%C3%A7ois-hugo/23/724/2a2 Dr. François Hugo], ex-[[Human Resources|HR Director]], [[FirstRand Group]]{{cite web|last=Symphonia|first=Board|title=Symphonia for South Africa {{!}} Community Leaders|url=http://www.symphonia.net/board_of_directors_francois.htm|work=Symphonia for South Africa {{!}} Community Leaders|publisher=Symphonia for South Africa {{!}} Community Leaders}} * [http://pk.linkedin.com/pub/shahpur-jamall/25/13/93b Shahpur Jamall], Founder Member & Academic Director, [Bay View Academy Karachi & Emeritus Principal of [[Southshore School for A-Level Studies|SouthShore School]]{{cite web|last=SchoolSearchPlus|first=Pakistan|title=Shahpur Jamall|url=http://www.schoolsearchplus.com/author/shahpur|work=SchoolSearchPlus|publisher=SchoolSearchPlus}} == {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2015}} {{Infobox magazine | image_file = | image_size = | image_caption = | editor = [[Yasser Akkaoui]] | editor_title = [[Editor-in-chief]] | frequency = Monthly | circulation = | category = [[Business journalism|Business magazine]] | company = | publisher = | firstdate = {{start date and age|1999}} | country = [[Lebanon]] | based = [[Beirut]] | language = [[English language|English]] | website = [http://www.executive-magazine.com/ ''Executive''] | issn = | oclc = }} '''''Executive''''' is an English language monthly business magazine published in Beirut, Lebanon. The magazine is one of the major publications concerning economic and financial matters across the Middle East and North Africa ([[MENA]]) region.<ref name=sims>{{cite news|author=Simona Sikimic|title=Executive magazine awarded for auditing transparency|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Lebanon-News/2010/Apr-02/56430-executive-magazine-awarded-for-auditing-transparency.ashx|accessdate=7 June 2015|work=The Daily Star|date=2 April 2010|location=Beirut}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=What to read on Lebanon|url=https://www.economist.com/blogs/pomegranate/2013/12/what-read|accessdate=7 June 2015|work=The Economist|date=4 December 2013}}</ref>
==History and profile== ''Executive'' was established in 1999.<ref>{{cite web|title=Speakers. Yasser Akkaoui|url=http://www.bdlaccelerate.com/speakers/yasser-akkaoui/|work=Banque du Liban|accessdate=7 June 2015|date=2014}}</ref> The magazine is published in Beirut on a monthly basis.<ref name=sims/> [[Yasser Akkaoui]] is the [[editor-in-chief]] of the monthly,<ref name=sims/> which covers articles on business and finance as well as on social, economic and cultural news in Lebanon.<ref>{{cite web|author=Lorenzo Trombetta|title=Media landscapes. Lebanon|url=http://ejc.net/media_landscapes/lebanon|work=European Journalism Centre|accessdate=7 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=Paul Doyle|title=Lebanon|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tzsRk0hvb_MC&pg=PA82|accessdate=7 June 2015|date=1 March 2012|publisher=Bradt Travel Guides|isbn=978-1-84162-370-2|page=82}}</ref>
In 2010 ''Executive'' became a member of the Business Publications Audit (BPA) Worldwide.<ref name=sims/>
==See also== [[List of magazines in Lebanon]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.executive-magazine.com/ Official website]

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} {{ad|date=June 2017}} '''The Fuld-Gilad-Herring Academy of Competitive Intelligence''' is an educational organization bringing professional training to the field of [[competitive intelligence]] (CI).<ref>[http://www.scip.org/Publications/CIMagIssueDetail.cfm?ItemNumber=1988 CI Education Issue]</ref> Established in 1996, the Academy has expanded its training to thousands of managers from 58 countries and six continents at its campuses in [[Cambridge, MA]] and [[Brussels, Belgium]]. The Academy is the only CI-dedicated institution to be externally accredited by the [[International Association of Continuing Education and Training]] (IACET).<ref>[http://www.academyci.com The Academy's web site]</ref> It grants the Competitive Intelligence Professional (CIP) certification based on a 9-course program, including a course in ethics and a pioneering course in business war gaming.<ref>Allan Hall, “Military moves on the corporate battlefield”, The Evening Standard, 8 May 2002</ref><ref>Dale Buss, “Berlitz for the boss”, Chief Executive, 1 December 2001, p. 38</ref> To be certified, managers must complete the required coursework and pass a certification exam. To accommodate managers whose main interest is in using CI tools and managers working as CI professionals, the Academy offers two levels of certification: a basic CIP-I, and an advanced CIP-II. The Academy is currently the largest training institute in its field.<ref>[http://www.academyci.com/About/alumni.html]</ref>
== Competitive Intelligence Standards ==
On March, 2011, the board of the professional association in the field of competitive intelligence- '''SCIP''' (Strategic and Competitive Intelligence Professionals) voted to adopt the Academy's CIP program as its official global certification program to help create standards in the field of strategic and competitive intelligence. The certification was renamed SCIP-CIP certificate conferred by ACI.<ref>http://info.intelligencecareers.com/index.php/2011/03/22/2011-06-1324-certification-in-competitive-intelligence-boston-massachusetts/</ref>
==History==
The history of the Academy tracks closely the history of the field of competitive intelligence which has risen in importance during the 1980s with the increase in global competitive pressures and the spread of [[Internet search engines]] which made information more accessible. In 1986, the [[Society of Competitive Intelligence Professionals]] (SCIP) was founded in Washington, DC to serve as the professional association for academics, practitioners and consultants in CI. During the next decade, organizations experimented in acquiring and using CI with little discipline and no consistent results. For example, as a survey by the Academy showed, one of CI's main objectives, avoiding strategic surprises, was not being accomplished in many large companies.<ref>George S. Day and Paul J.H. Schoemaker, “Scanning the Periphery”, ''Harvard Business Review'', November 2005, p. 135.</ref> Three early developers of the Society banded together to create a standard of training and performance in the field. They were: Leonard Fuld, whose book, ''Competitor Intelligence'', was the first best seller on the subject,<ref>Fuld, Leonard, ''Competitor Intelligence: How to get it, how to use it''. NY: Wiley, 1985. {{ISBN|978-0471809678}}</ref> [[Benjamin Gilad|Ben Gilad]], whose book The Business Intelligence System created the benchmark for setting up a corporate CI function,<ref>Gilad, Ben and Tamar Gilad, The Business Intelligence System. NY: American Management Association, 1988</ref> and Jan Herring who was the founding director of the first competitive intelligence function created in 1982 at [[Motorola]] Corp.<ref>Herring, Jan P. Measuring the Effectiveness of Competitive Intelligence: Assessing & Communicating CI's Value to Your Organization. Virginia: Society of Competitive Intelligence Professionals, 1996</ref> Together with the growth of SCIP, the creation of the Academy accelerated greatly the formalization and acceptance of CI functions and positions across global companies, with some estimating that 97% of Fortune 500 corporations today have at least one CI analyst in each of their larger business units.<ref>Matthew Boyle, “The Prying Game: A little knowledge is a dangerous...weapon. No wonder competitive intelligence schools are on the rise.” Fortune Magazine, Advisor/Careers, 17 September 2001, Vol. 144, (5), p. 235.</ref>
==Competition==
As the field continued to evolve, several organizations in recent years have joined the Academy in offering training programs in competitive intelligence, mostly as an extension of other degree programs, among them [[Mercyhurst College Institute for Intelligence Studies]] in PA (an extension of a government intelligence program), [[Simmons College (Massachusetts)|Simmons College]] in MA (part of Library and Information studies), and the [[University of Denver]] in CO (part of a graduate degree in information management). Other programs include the [[Ecole de Guerre Economique]] in France and Institute for Competitive Intelligence in Germany. Entry level courses are also offered by the Society of Competitive Intelligence Professionals.
==Student body==
The functional distribution of the Academy's alumni body covers managers and professionals from competitive and market intelligence functions, [[marketing]], [[market research]], [[business development]], [[strategic planning]], research scientists and development engineers. Though the typical trainee is a manager at a Global Fortune 500 company, past participants included some unusual representatives from the [[Catholic Church]], various governments' defense agencies, farmer cooperatives, national economic development boards, and a Cabinet Minister.
==Faculty== *Leonard M. Fuld [http://www.academyci.com/About/fuld.html] *Michael Sandman, B.S. (Clark University), MA, M.B.A. (Cornell University) [http://www.academyci.com/About/sandman.html] *Dr. Helen Rothberg, Ph.D., MPhil. (City University of New York), MBA (City University of New York at Baruch College), associate professor at Marist College School of Management *Jan Herring, BSc. (University of Missouri) [http://www.academyci.com/About/rothberg.html] *Ashish Nanda, A.M.(Harvard University), Ph.D.(Harvard Business School), associate professor at the Harvard Law School [http://www.academyci.com/About/nanda.html] *Jules Schwartz, Ph.D. (Harvard Business School), former dean and a professor emeritus of Boston University School of Management, former faculty member Wharton School [http://www.academyci.com/About/schwartz.html] *Dr. Ben Gilad, former strategy professor at Rutgers University School of Management [https://web.archive.org/web/20090106124414/http://www.academyci.com/About/gilad.html] *Jay Paap, Ph.D.(MIT Sloan), has held faculty positions at Sloan and Indiana University [http://www.academyci.com/About/paap.html] *Dan Mulligan, M.A. (USMA Westpoint), Assistant Professor at the Mercyhurst College Institute for Intelligence Studies [http://www.academyci.com/About/mulliganD.html]
==Advisory board==
The Academy's advisory board includes executives from US-based [[Intel]], [[Procter and Gamble]], [[Genentech]], [[Blue Cross Blue Shield]], [[Microsoft]], [[Fidelity]] and [[Wyeth]] corporations, as well as Europe-based [[Royal Dutch Shell|Shell]], [[Hoffmann-La Roche|Roche]], [[TetraPak]] and [[Orange (brand)|Orange]], and Mexico-based [[Cemex]].
==Sources== 1. http://www.scip.org/Publications/CIMagIssueDetail.cfm?ItemNumber=1988 2. Herring, Jan P. Measuring the Effectiveness of Competitive Intelligence: Assessing & Communicating CI's Value to Your Organization. Virginia: Society of Competitive Intelligence Professionals, 1996. 3. Fuld, Leonard, Competitor Intelligence: How to get it, how to use it. NY: Wiley, 1985. 4. Gilad, Ben and Tamar Gilad, The Business Intelligence System. NY: American Management Association, 1988. 5. www.academyci.com 6. Matthew Boyle, “The Prying Game: A little knowledge is a dangerous...weapon. No wonder competitive intelligence schools are on the rise.” Fortune Magazine, Advisor/Careers, 17 September 2001, Vol. 144, (5), p. 235. 7. Allan Hall, “Military moves on the corporate battlefield”, The Evening Standard, 8 May, 2002. 8. Dale Buss, “Berlitz for the boss”, Chief Executive, 1 December 2001, p. 38. 9. George S. Day and Paul J.H. Schoemaker, “Scanning the Periphery”, Harvard Business Review, November 2005, p. 135.
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Fuld-Gilad-Herring Academy Of Competitive Intelligence}} [[Category:Business intelligence]] [[Category:Market research]] [[Category:Strategic management]] [[Category:Competition (economics)]]

The analysis of the global environment of a company is called '''global environmental analysis'''. This analysis is part of a company’s analysis-system, which also comprises various other analyses, like the industry analysis, the [[market analysis]] and the analyses of companies, clients and [[competitors]]. This system can be divided into a macro and micro level. Except for the global environmental analysis, all other analyses can be found on the micro level. Though, the global environmental analysis describes the macro environment of a company.<ref>{{cite book|last=Dillerup|first=R.|title=Unternehmensführung|year=2006|publisher=Vahlen|location=München|pages=179}}</ref> Obviously, a company is influenced by its environment. Many environmental factors, especially economical or social factors, play a big role in a company’s decisions, because the analysis and the monitoring of those factors reveal chances and risks for the company’s business. This environmental framework also gives information about location issues. A company is thereby able to determine its location sites. Furthermore, many other strategic decisions are based on this analysis. One may also apply the BBW model.<ref>{{cite book|last=Kohlöffel|first=K. M.|title=Strategisches Management – Alle Chancen nutzen – Neue Geschäfte erschließen|year=2000|publisher=Carl Hanser Verlag|location=München Wien|page=125}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Dillerup|first=R.|title=Unternehmensführung|year=2006|publisher=Vahlen|location=München|page=179}}</ref> In addition, the factors are analyzed to evaluate external business developments.<ref>{{cite book|last=Bleicher|first=K.|title=Das Konzept Integriertes Management – Visionen, Missionen, Programme, 7th edition|year=2004|location=Frankfurt/Main, Campus|page=536}}</ref> It is finally the task of the management to adapt the firm to its environment or to influence the environment in an adequate way. The latter is mostly the more difficult option. There are different instruments to analyze the company’s environment which are going to be explained afterwards.
==PESTLE analysis== One instrument to analyse the company’s external environment is the [[PEST analysis]]. PEST stands for political, economical, social and technological factors. Two more factors, the legal and environmental factor, are defined within the PESTLE analysis.<ref>{{cite book|last=Jeffs|first=C.|title=Strategic Management|year=2008|publisher=SAGE Publications Ltd.|pages=29}}</ref> To explain these environmental factors, it is necessary to say that most of the factors depend on each other and that they change over the years. Consequently, when one factor changes it also affects the others. The equality for every company is the main characteristic of the factors in an environmental analysis.<ref>{{cite book|last=Bea, F.X.|first=Haas, J.|title=Strategisches Management, 4th edition|year=2005|publisher=Lucius & Lucius|location=Stuttgart}}</ref> The different environmental factors are covered below.
===Political and legal factors=== Political and legal factors are here regarded as a unit. They refer to framework given by politics. The exist regulatory or legal frameworks, which can be binding for regions, nations or on an international basis. The frameworks deal with economical issues or issues concerning the [[Labour economics|labour market]].[[Subsidies]] for instance fall in the category of economical issues. According to the degree of support through subsidies, a country can be more or less attractive for a company. With respect to the [[labour law]] of a country, it can highly influence location decisions, too. If e.g. the dismissal protection in a country is very good, a firm may tend to choose a country with a more flexible hire-and-fire-system. Furthermore, the stability of a political system is a real important aspect for most firms. A [[social market economy]] with rights for co-determination, regulations for patents, the company’s investment and environment protection are main characteristics for a political stable system.
===Economical factors=== Economical factors deal with national or international economical developments and have a direct influence on supplier and consumer markets. Examples of economical factors that play a big role are: the [[GDP]], the [[Inflation rate|rate of inflation]], interests, the change rate, employment or the situation of money markets. These economical factors influence demand, competition intensity, cost pressure and the will to invest. For instance, if the gross domestic product of a country is fairly low, the demand is in general lower than in countries with a higher GDP.
===Social factors=== Social factors deal with social issues regarding the values, ideas, opinions and the culture of market participants. Market participants can be employees, customers or suppliers. Through their contact with the company, they influence it due to their opinions. The company needs to follow the market participant’s change of value and adapt its strategies. Nowadays, a change of values concerning [[environmental protection]] is on the move.
===Technological environmental factors=== Technological environmental factors are meanwhile of a great importance, especially for industrial companies, which underlie a fast technological change. The increasing speed of technological changes, like in microelectronics or robotics indicate risks chances for a company. Particularly producing companies are affected of that fast evolution.
===Environmental factors=== At last, environmental factors are becoming more and more important nowadays. They regard [[natural resources]] and the basis of human life. Among those, the availability of raw materials and energy is the main topic. As the availability of fossil fuels, like oil or coal, gets worse within the next decades, the dependency on those fuels stays pretty risky. Moreover, to show an ecological responsibility, companies should assess and reduce their ecological damage. Through rare raw materials and increasing pollution, an environmentally friendly management gets spotlighted more and more by the public interest. Consequently, [[Sustainable products|eco-friendly products]] or technologies can even signify a competitive advantage.<ref>{{cite book|last=Dillerup|first=R.|title=Unternehmensführung|year=2006|publisher=Vahlen|location=München|pages=180}}</ref>
==Methods of the global environmental analysis== The [[Market segmentation|segmentation]] according to the six presented factors of the PESTLE analysis is the starting point of the global environmental analysis. The analysis can be done with the help of a checklist that evaluates every criteria of a segment. In this manner, the status of the global environment shall be defined. In general, every segment needs to be worked on systematically to recognize changes. Then, the factors and its impacts can be interpreted right. After the segmentation, the analysis consists of four further steps: # Environmental Scanning # Environmental Monitoring # Environmental Forecasting # Environmental Assessment
===Environmental scanning===
The first step is called scanning. Through [[environmental scanning]], every segment is analyzed to find trend indicators. Thus, after having examined the segment, indicators for its development are defined.<ref name="DR 183">{{cite book|last=Dillerup|first=R.|title=Unternehmensführung|year=2006|publisher=Vahlen|location=München|page=183}}</ref> According to Fahey and Narayanan, scanning reveals ‘actual or imminent change because it explicitly focuses on areas that the organisation may have previously neglected’.<ref>{{cite book|last=Mercer|first=D.|title=Marketing strategy: the challenge of external environment|year=1998|publisher=The Open University|pages=57}}</ref> Scanning is also used to detect weak signals in the environment, before these have conflated into a recognizable pattern, which might affect the organization’s competitive environment.
Scanning can include every material published in the media such as television, newspapers and periodicals.<ref>{{cite book|last=Mercer|first=D.|title=Marketing strategy: the challenge of external environment|year=1998|publisher=The Open University|page=56}}</ref> This method of scanning is called media-scanning. Product-scanning includes scanning of products which announce re-emerging consumer behaviour. Looking for global trends on the internet can be defined as online-scanning.<ref>{{cite book|last=Neu|first=M.|title=Unternehmensführung, 2nd edition|year=2005|publisher=BWV|page=107}}</ref>
'''Modes of scanning'''
Four modes of scanning can be distinguished. Francis Joseph Aguilar (1967) differentiates between undirected viewing, conditioned viewing, informal search and formal search. *'Undirected viewing' means reading a variety of publications for no specific purpose with the possible exception of exploration. This mode is the most cost-efficient one but it also offers the most benefits. There are a lot of varied sources and information which means that the potential data are unlimited. Data are imprecise and vague and there are no guidelines which determine where the search should be focused. *Applying 'conditioned viewing' the viewer pays attention to the particular kinds of data and assesses their significance for the organization. The field of information is more or less clearly identified. *'Informal searching' can be defined as actively seeking specific information in a relatively unstructured way. *The contrast of informal searching is called 'formal searching'. This proactive mode of scanning contains methodologies for obtaining information for specific purposes.<ref>{{cite book|last=Mercer|first=D.|title=Marketing strategy: the challenge of external environment|year=1998|publisher=The Open University|page=57}}</ref>
===Environmental monitoring===
Environmental scanning is only one component of global environmental analysis. After having identified critical trends and potential events they have to be monitored. The next step in global environmental analysis is called [[environmental monitoring]]. It can be defined as 'the process of repetitive observing for defined purposes, of one or more elements or indicators of the environment according to pre-arranged schedules in space and time, and using comparable methodologies for environmental sensing and data collection'.<ref>{{cite book|last=Von Agarwal|first=S. K.|title=Environmental monitoring|year=2005|publisher=APH Publishing Corporation|location=Kul Bhushan Nangia|page=2}}</ref> Through environmental monitoring, data about environmental developments are recorded, followed and interpreted. Out of this, historical development changes that are important for the company can be recognized and evaluated. Additionally, the relevance and the reliability of the data sources are tested. Furthermore, it is checked where prognoses are required.
===Environmental forecasting===
The direction, intensity and speed of environmental trends are explored through environmental [[forecasting]]. Especially the search for possible threats is of importance. A [[Prediction|prognosis]] of trends is necessary to get a picture of the future. This is done by adequate methods, like [[strategic foresight]] or [[scenario analysis]].<ref name="DR 183"/> Several other methods of forecasting are the following: guessing, [[rule of thumb]], expert judgement, [[extrapolation]], [[Economic indicator|leading indicators]], surveys, [[time-series]] models and econometric systems.<ref>{{cite book|last=Clements, M. P.|first=Hendry, D. F.|title=A companion to economic forecasting|year=2002|publisher=Blackwell Publishers Ltd.|pages=3}}</ref>
* 'Guessing' and related methods totally rely on luck. Consequently, it is not generally a useful method. In addition, it is almost impossible to evaluate the uncertainty of a guess in advance. * 'Expert judgement' lacks validation being the only component of forecasting. It is hardly to predict which ‘oracle’ is successful. * 'Extrapolation' is effective when tendencies exist. Forecasts are most effective when changes are predicted in tendencies. Prediction in changes in tendencies is likely to miss concerning extrapolative methods. * 'Forecasting based on leading indicators' needs a stable relationship between the variables that lead and the variables that are led. If the reasons for the lead are not clear the indicators may give misleading information. * 'Surveys' of businesses can give information about the future. They rely on planning which needs to be realized. Changes in business implicate changes in planning. * 'Time-series models' are popular forecasting methods. They describe historical patterns of data and they focus on “measurable uncertainty”. * 'Econometric systems' of equations are the main tool of economic forecasting. They consist of equations which attempt to “model” the behaviour of economic groups such as consumers, producers, workers, investors etc. moderated by historical experience. There are several advantages of using formal econometric systems: Economists are able 'to consolidate existing empirical and theoretical knowledge..., provide a framework for a progressive research strategy..., help to explain their own failures, as well as provide forecasts and policy advice.'<ref>{{cite book|last=Clements, M. P.|first=Hendry, D. F.|title=A companion to economic forecasting|year=2002|publisher=Blackwell Publishers Ltd.|pages=4}}</ref>
===Environmental assessment===
In the last step of the global environmental analysis, the results of the previous three steps (Scanning, Monitoring, Forecasting) are assessed. The discovered environmental trends are reviewed to estimate the probability of their occurrence. Furthermore, they need to be analyzed to evaluate whether they represent a chance or a risk for the company. The dimension of the chances or risks is also of importance. Moreover, a reaction strategy to the occurring risks or chances needs to be defined. This is done with the help of the Issue-Impact-Matrix, an adequate instrument to evaluate and prioritize trends. The forecasted environmental factors are here classified with respect to their probability of occurrence and their impact on the company. According to their classification, they demonstrate a high, medium or low priority for the company. The factors with a high occurrence probability and a high, significant impact on the company have the highest priority. The higher the priority, the faster need to be reacted to avoid risks and to benefit from chances.<ref>{{cite book|last=Dillerup, R.|first=Stoi, R.|title=Unternehmensführung, 3rd edition|year=2011|publisher=Vahlen|location=München|page=75}}</ref> The environmental assessment represents the last step of the global environmental analysis.
