{{Distinguish|Kate O'Mara|Rooney Mara}} {{Use mdy dates|date=March 2017}} {{Infobox person | name = Kate Mara | image = Kate Mara by Gage Skidmore.jpg | caption = Mara in 2015 | birth_name = Kate Rooney Mara | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|mf=yes|1983|2|27}} | birth_place = [[Bedford (town), New York|Bedford, New York]], U.S. | residence = [[Los Angeles]], [[California]], U.S. | othername = Katherine Rooney Mara | occupation = Actress, fashion model | years_active = 1997–present | spouse = {{marriage|[[Jamie Bell]]|2017}} | family = [[Rooney family|Rooney]], [[Rooney family#Mara connection|Mara]] | relatives = [[Rooney Mara]] (sister) }}
'''Kate Rooney Mara''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|m|ɛər|ə}} {{respell|MAIR|ə}};<ref>{{cite podcast |url=https://soundcloud.com/happysadconfused/kate-mara |title=Kate Mara |website=Happy Sad Confused |publisher=[[SoundCloud]] |host=Josh Horowitz |time=1:53 |date=February 23, 2014 |accessdate=August 11, 2015}}</ref> born February 27, 1983)<ref name=tvg>{{cite web|url=http://www.tvguide.com/celebrities/kate-mara/190291|title=Kate Mara|publisher=[[TV Guide]]|accessdate=September 1, 2014}}</ref> is an American actress and fashion model. She is known for her roles as reporter [[Zoe Barnes]] in the [[Netflix]] political drama ''[[House of Cards (U.S. TV series)|House of Cards]]'' (2013–2014; 2016), computer analyst Shari Rothenberg in the [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] thriller series ''[[24 (TV series)|24]]'' (2006) and [[Ben Harmon]]'s vengeful mistress [[List of American Horror Story characters#Hayden McClaine|Hayden McClaine]] in the [[FX (TV channel)|FX]] horror miniseries ''[[American Horror Story: Murder House]]'' (2011).
She made her film debut in 1999 with ''[[Random Hearts]]''. She has since appeared in ''[[Brokeback Mountain]]'' (2005), ''[[We Are Marshall]]'' (2006), ''[[Shooter (2007 film)|Shooter]]'' (2007), ''[[Transsiberian (film)|Transsiberian]]'' (2008), ''[[Stone of Destiny (film)|Stone of Destiny]]'' (2008), ''[[The Open Road]]'' (2009), ''[[Transcendence (2014 film)|Transcendence]]'' (2014), ''[[The Martian (film)|The Martian]]'' (2015), ''[[Fantastic Four (2015 film)|Fantastic Four]]'' (2015), ''[[Morgan (2016 film)|Morgan]]'' (2016), ''[[Megan Leavey (film)|Megan Leavey]]'' (2017) and ''[[Chappaquiddick (film)|Chappaquiddick]]'' (2018), portraying [[Mary Jo Kopechne]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?time_continue=3&v=qG-c8DtOm9g|title=CHAPPAQUIDDICK Official Trailer (2018) Kate Mara, Kennedy Biography Movie HD|first=|last=ONE Media|date=December 20, 2017|publisher=|via=YouTube}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=i9SCbC6HDEU|title=CHAPPAQUIDDICK Official Trailer # 2 (2018) Kate Mara, Kennedy Biography Movie HD|first=|last=ONE Media|date=February 28, 2018|publisher=|via=YouTube}}</ref>
==Early life== Kate Rooney Mara was born and raised in [[Bedford (town), New York|Bedford, New York]]. Her parents are Timothy Christopher Mara, an [[National Football League|NFL]] [[Scout (sport)|scout]] and vice president of the [[New York Giants]] for player evaluation, and Kathleen McNulty Mara (née [[Rooney family|Rooney]]).<ref name="maraug">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1980/12/24/archives/notes-on-people-its-goodbye-for-a-longtime-greeter-mara-and-rooney.html|title=Notes on People; It's Goodbye for a Long-Time Greeter Mara and Rooney Clans to Gather at Wedding Rudolf Bing Speaks His Mind About the Met Former Student Musician Has a New Role Santa Gets a Helper|last=Bird|first=David|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=December 24, 1980|accessdate=April 30, 2010}} (fee required)</ref> She is the second of four siblings, with one older brother, Daniel; one younger sister, the actress [[Rooney Mara|Rooney (born Patricia)]]; and one younger brother, Conor.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.irishcentral.com/culture/entertainment/exclusive-interview-with-kate-mara-co-star-of-channing-tatum-in-10-years-video-170675236-237529501|title=Exclusive interview with Kate Mara co-star of Channing Tatum in "10 Years" - VIDEO|date=September 21, 2012|publisher=}}</ref> Mara's father has [[Irish American|Irish]], [[German American|German]], and [[French Canadian]] ancestry, and her mother is of [[British Empire|British]] and [[Italian American|Italian]] descent.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.irishcentral.com/roots/genealogy/7-irish-americans-you-didn-t-know-had-irish-roots|title=7 celebrities you didn’t know had Irish roots|date=December 14, 2016|publisher=}}</ref>
She is a great-granddaughter of both [[New York Giants]] founder [[Tim Mara]] and [[Pittsburgh Steelers]] founder [[Art Rooney|Art Rooney, Sr.]]<ref name="Post-Gazette">"[http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/08346/934457-66.stm Steelers, Giants memorabilia auctioned to help Kenyan orphans]". December 11, 2008. ''[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]''.</ref> Her mother's side of the family has held ownership in the NFL's [[Pittsburgh Steelers]] football team since its formation in 1933, and her father's side of the family has held ownership in the NFL's [[New York Giants]] since its formation in 1925. Her paternal grandparents were [[Wellington Mara]] and [[Ann Mara]]. Wellington co-owned the Giants football team from 1959 until his death in 2005, and was succeeded by his son (Kate Mara's uncle), [[John Mara]], who is currently President, CEO, and co-owner of the team. Kate Mara's maternal grandfather, Timothy James "Tim" Rooney, has run [[Yonkers Raceway]] in [[Yonkers, New York]] since 1972.<ref name="Newsday">{{cite web|url=http://www.newsday.com/sports/football/ny-spmara0131,0,6745598.story|title=Rooney Mara links NFL's two royal families|last=Staple|first=Arthur|publisher=[[Newsday]]|date=January 30, 2009|accessdate=January 31, 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090203132126/http://www.newsday.com/sports/football/ny-spmara0131,0,6745598.story|archive-date=February 3, 2009|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/05/style/eileen-hawthorn-engaged-to-wed-t-j-rooney-jr.html|title=Eileen Hawthorn Engaged to Wed T. J. Rooney Jr.|work=The New York Times|date=November 5, 1989}}</ref> Her granduncle, [[Dan Rooney]], chairman of the Steelers, was a former [[United States Ambassador to Ireland]] and the co-founder of the charitable organization [[The Ireland Funds]]. Her first cousin, once removed, [[Art Rooney II]], is the current President and co-owner of the Steelers.
Mara began acting at the age of nine in a school musical. She attended several youth theater-arts schools and appeared in [[community theatre|community theater]] and in school [[Play (theatre)|plays]].<ref name="Lynch">Lynch, Lorrie (July 30, 2006). [http://www.usaweekend.com/06_issues/060730/060730whosnews.html "Who's News"]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}. ''[[USA Weekend]]''. Retrieved February 27, 2007.</ref><ref>''[[Nip/Tuck]]'' media guide. 2003. [[FX Networks]].</ref> Mara has described herself to ''[[Esquire (magazine)|Esquire]]'' magazine as having been "painfully shy" while growing up, adding that she only had one friend.<ref>Cabot, Tyler (January 29, 2009). [http://www.esquire.com/entertainment/interviews/a5561/kate-mara-naked-0309/ "Kate Mara Is Ready for the Super Bowl"]. ''[[Esquire (magazine)|Esquire]]''. Retrieved January 31, 2007.</ref>
Her first audition was for the [[NBC]] police drama ''[[Homicide: Life on the Street]]''. She did not get the role but knew from then on that she just wanted to act. Mara graduated from [[Fox Lane High School]] a year early and was accepted into the [[Tisch School of the Arts]] at [[New York University]] to study musical theater, but she eventually deferred her slot to work as an actress.{{Citation needed|date=October 2012}}
==Career== [[File:Kate Mara 2008.jpg|thumb|Mara at the [[2008 Sundance Film Festival]] in January 2008]]
===Television and stage=== Mara's first television role was in the NBC legal drama ''[[Law & Order]]'' in 1997. She went on to guest star on numerous television series, including ''[[Madigan Men]]'', ''[[Ed (TV series)|Ed]]'' and ''[[Law & Order: Special Victims Unit]]''. Mara landed two recurring roles in 2003, as Kate on ''[[Everwood]]'', an 18-year-old who is impregnated by her piano teacher and then gets an abortion, and as Vanessa on ''[[Nip/Tuck]]'', a [[bisexual]] cheerleader involved in a [[love triangle]] with her boyfriend [[Matt McNamara]] ([[John Hensley]]) and another cheerleader ([[Sophia Bush]]).<ref>Warn, Sarah (September 2003). "[http://www.afterellen.com/archive/ellen/TV/nip-tuck.html Nip/Tuck Increases Lesbian Visibility by Leaps/Bounds] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080920013954/http://www.afterellen.com/archive/ellen/TV/nip-tuck.html |date=September 20, 2008 }}". [[AfterEllen.com]]. Retrieved on September 7, 2008.</ref> Mara also appeared on ''[[Cold Case (TV series)|Cold Case]]'', ''[[Boston Public]]'', ''[[CSI: Miami]]'' and ''[[CSI: Crime Scene Investigation]]'' that same year.
Mara was cast as the lead in the 2004 [[The WB]] [[Television pilot|pilot]] ''Prodigy'', about a teenage [[child prodigy]].<ref>"Casting Call". March 4, 2004. ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]''.</ref> She had a recurring role on the WB's ''[[Jack & Bobby]]'' in 2005 and a five-episode arc on the [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] TV series ''[[24 (season 5)|24]]'' in 2006, playing computer analyst [[Minor CTU agents in 24#24: Season 5|Shari Rothenberg]]. Mara joined the cast of the [[HBO]] comedy-drama ''[[Entourage (U.S. TV series)|Entourage]]'' for the series' sixth season in 2009. She played Brittany, [[Eric Murphy|Eric "E" Murphy]] ([[Kevin Connolly (actor)|Kevin Connolly]])'s assistant at his talent-management company and a potential love interest.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tvguide.com/News/Entourage-casting-Mara-1005458.aspx|title=Entourage News: 24 Alumna Clocks In as E's Assistant|last=O'Connor|first=Mickey|publisher=[[TV Guide]]|date=April 25, 2009|accessdate=April 25, 2009}}</ref> Mara filmed four episodes for the series in 2009.<ref name="NYPost-2009-07-12"/> In 2011, she guest starred on the [[FX (TV channel)|FX]] horror series ''[[American Horror Story]]'', as [[List of American Horror Story characters#Hayden McClaine|Hayden McClaine]], a student who becomes [[Dr. Ben Harmon]] ([[Dylan McDermott]])'s dead mistress, a spirit trapped in the Harmon house. Mara was offered the role by [[Ryan Murphy (writer)|Ryan Murphy]], her former producer on ''Nip/Tuck''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/gossip/2011/12/kate-mara-rooney-mara-dragon-tattoo-american-horror-story.htm|title=Kate Mara on the Rooney Mara rivalry, 'American Horror Story'|last=Donnelly|first=Matt|publisher=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=December 19, 2011|accessdate=December 22, 2011}}</ref>
In 2012, Mara joined the cast of ''[[House of Cards (U.S. TV series)|House of Cards]]'', playing the part of Zoe Barnes, an intrepid reporter from [[Washington, D.C.]] who becomes a major ally to [[Frank Underwood (House of Cards)|Frank Underwood]] by leaking stories that undermine his rivals.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.deadline.com/2012/02/jennifer-finnigan-cast-in-david-e-kelleys-tnt-pilot-kate-mata-in-netflix-series-house-of-cards/|title=Jennifer Finnigan Joins David E. Kelley TNT Pilot, Kate Mara in Netflix ‘House of Cards’|last=Andreeva|first=Nellie|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=February 1, 2012|accessdate=February 7, 2012}}</ref> She filmed a [[House of Cards (season 2)|second season]] of the series, which was released on February 14, 2014. On July 10, 2014, she was nominated for the [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Guest Actress in a Drama Series]].
She made her stage debut in 2003 at the [[Williamstown Theatre Festival]] in [[John Guare]]'s ''[[Landscape of the Body]]'' with [[Lili Taylor]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://theater2.nytimes.com/mem/theater/treview.html?_r=1&html_title=&tols_title=LANDSCAPE%20OF%20THE%20BODY%20(PLAY)&pdate=20030719&byline=By%20BEN%20BRANTLEY&id=1077011430538&oref=slogin|title=The Allure Of an Empty Paradise|last=Brantley|first=Ben|publisher=The New York Times|date=July 19, 2003|accessdate=February 23, 2007}}</ref> Mara starred in ''The Alice Complex'', a play by Peter Barr Nickowitz, at [[Dixon Place]] in New York City in 2005 and at the [[Blank Theatre]] in Los Angeles in 2006. The production co-starred [[Tony Award]]-winner [[Harriet Harris]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://broadwayworld.com/viewcolumn.cfm?colid=30160|title='The Alice Complex' to Star Elbrick and Banes|work=Broadwayworld.com|date=July 18, 2008}}</ref> She later told [[WFAN]] radio in 2006 that doing more theater work is a "dream" because it was "all I really wanted to do as a kid. I didn't care about movies or TV, I just wanted to do Broadway".<ref name="WFAN">[[Mike Francesa|Francesa, Mike]]; [[Chris Russo|Russo, Chris]] (December 11, 2006). "The Fan – Kate Mara interview". ''[[Mike and the Mad Dog]]''.</ref>
===Film=== Mara made her film debut in ''[[Random Hearts (film)|Random Hearts]]'', with [[Harrison Ford]] in 1999, directed by [[Sydney Pollack]]. She played Jessica Chandler, the daughter of a [[congresswoman]] ([[Kristin Scott Thomas]]). She next appeared in the [[Sundance Film Festival]] award-winning films ''[[Joe the King]]'' (1999) and ''[[Tadpole (film)|Tadpole]]'' (2002), alongside [[Sigourney Weaver]]. Mara co-starred in ''Peoples'' (2004), a drama and [[coming of age]] story filmed in [[Louisville, Kentucky]]. She starred in the [[direct-to-video]] horror film ''[[Urban Legends: Bloody Mary]]'' and appeared with [[Noah Wyle]] and [[Illeana Douglas]] in the 2005 film ''[[The Californians (film)|The Californians]]''. Her supporting role as the daughter of [[Heath Ledger]]'s character in the [[Academy Awards|Academy Award]]-winning film ''[[Brokeback Mountain]]'' that year brought her more widespread critical notice.<ref name="Lynch"/>
Mara signed with the [[William Morris Agency]],<ref name="Dodd">{{cite web|url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117936011.html?categoryId=29&cs=1|title=Kate Mara|last=Dodd|first=Stacy|magazine=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=January 13, 2006|accessdate=February 27, 2007}}</ref> and was included on the ''[[New York Daily News]]'' list of "10 young actors who have a shot at making it big" at the start of 2006.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/nydn-features/em-shine-annual-roundup-10-young-actors-shot-making-big-article-1.617760|title=LET 'EM SHINE. Here's our annual roundup of 10 young actors who have a shot at making it big|last=Mills|first=Nancy|newspaper=[[Daily News (New York)|New York Daily News]]|date=January 1, 2006|accessdate=August 4, 2015}}</ref> She appeared in ''[[Zoom (2006 film)|Zoom]]'' that year as Summer Jones (aka Wonder), a 16-year-old girl with [[Psychokinesis|telekinetic]] and [[Empathy|empathic]] abilities. She next appeared in ''[[We Are Marshall]]'', starring [[Matthew McConaughey]], which recalled the aftermath of the 1970 [[Marshall University]] plane crash that took the lives of most of the football team. Mara played cheerleader Annie Cantrell.<ref name="Vanities"/>
In 2007, she appeared in the comedy ''[[Full of It]]'' with [[Ryan Pinkston]] for [[New Line Cinema]]. The film later aired on television as ''Big Liar on Campus''. Mara was also featured in an advertising campaign for clothing retailer [[Gap (clothing retailer)|Gap]] called, "khakis with attitude."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.brandweek.com/bw/news/recent_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1003535139|title=Gap Campaign Features Khakis and Attitude|last=O'Loughlin|first=Sandra|publisher=[[Brandweek]]|date=January 19, 2007|accessdate=March 18, 2007}}</ref> She appeared in ''[[Shooter (2007 film)|Shooter]]'', a [[thriller (genre)|thriller]] about a master [[sniper]] portrayed by [[Mark Wahlberg]], lured out of retirement to prevent an [[assassination]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117941380?categoryid=1238&cs=1|title='Shooter' Targets Mara|last=Fleming|first=Michael|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=April 11, 2006|accessdate=February 27, 2007}}</ref> Mara played a [[Kentucky]] widow, Sarah Fenn, adopting a [[Southern American English|southern]] accent for the role.
Also in 2007, she finished her work in the film ''[[Transsiberian (film)|Transsiberian]]'' by [[Brad Anderson (film director)|Brad Anderson]], which takes place on the [[Trans-Siberian Railway]] that runs from [[China]] to [[Moscow]]. She spent three months shooting the thriller in [[Vilnius]], [[Lithuania]],<ref name="Longsdorf">Longsdorf, Amy (March 18, 2007). "[http://www.northjersey.com/page.php?qstr=eXJpcnk3ZjczN2Y3dnFlZUVFeXkxNjcmZmdiZWw3Zjd2cWVlRUV5eTcwOTQyNzMmeXJpcnk3ZjcxN2Y3dnFlZUVFeXk3 Mara's game plan: keep acting] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071013121719/http://northjersey.com/page.php?qstr=eXJpcnk3ZjczN2Y3dnFlZUVFeXkxNjcmZmdiZWw3Zjd2cWVlRUV5eTcwOTQyNzMmeXJpcnk3ZjcxN2Y3dnFlZUVFeXk3 |date=October 13, 2007 }}". [[North Jersey Media Group]]. {{Retrieved|accessdate=March 18, 2007}}. (dead link as of at least August 16, 2010)</ref> starting in December 2006. The film also shot on location in [[Beijing]] and [[Russia]].<ref>Hopewell, John & Fleming, Michael (November 30, 2006). "[http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117954866.html?categoryid=13&cs=1 Cast aboard for Anderson]". ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]''. Retrieved on February 27, 2007.</ref> Mara played Abby, a 20-year-old [[Runaway youth|runaway]] from [[Seattle]].<ref>"[http://www.moviesonline.ca/movienews_11526.html Kate Mara Interview, Shooter]". MoviesOnline. Retrieved on March 27, 2007.</ref> ''Transsiberian'' premiered at the [[2008 Sundance Film Festival]] in January 2008.
Mara starred in the 2008 film ''[[Stone of Destiny (film)|Stone of Destiny]]'', written and directed by [[Charles Martin Smith]], about the theft of the [[Stone of Scone]] on [[Christmas Day]], 1950. Mara played Kay Matheson, one of four students that removed the stone in a [[Scottish nationalist]] plot. The [[period piece|period]] adventure-comedy co-starred [[Billy Boyd (actor)|Billy Boyd]], [[Robert Carlyle]] and [[Charlie Cox]].<ref name="Scotsman">{{cite web|url=http://scotlandonsunday.scotsman.com/index.cfm?id=946702007|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071013122545/http://scotlandonsunday.scotsman.com/index.cfm?id=946702007|dead-url=yes|archive-date=October 13, 2007|title=Romancing the Stone: Scots heist destined for Hollywood|last=Pendreigh|first=Brian|publisher=[[Scotland on Sunday]]|date=June 17, 2007|accessdate=June 17, 2007}}</ref> Filming began in June 2007 in locations around [[Glasgow]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/scotland/tayside_and_central/6253378.stm|title=Stone of Destiny film under way|work=[[BBC News]]|date=June 29, 2007|accessdate=June 29, 2007}}</ref> Mara felt lucky and proud to play a role that was important to people's heritage.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com/Entertainment/article/588405|title=Her role carried weight of history|last=Barnard|first=Linda|work=[[Toronto Star]]|date=February 17, 2009|accessdate=February 18, 2009}}</ref> She stayed near the [[Glasgow Botanic Gardens|Botanic Gardens]] in the city's [[Glasgow#West End|West End]] while filming,<ref name="LateLateShow">"Kate Mara interview". ''[[The Late Late Show with Craig Ferguson]]''. August 12, 2008.</ref> attending the film premiere at the [[Edinburgh International Film Festival]] on June 21, 2008.<ref>[http://news.scotsman.com/entertainment/Destiny-calls-stars-to-premiere.4210264.jp "Destiny calls stars to premiere of Scone stone film"]. ''[[Edinburgh Evening News]]''. June 21, 2008. Retrieved June 21, 2008.</ref> The film closed the [[2008 Toronto International Film Festival]] on September 13, 2008.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thisisbristol.co.uk/Showbiz/Stone-Destiny-closes-Toronto/article-327441-detail/article.html|title=Stone Of Destiny closes Toronto|work=[[Bristol Evening Post]]|date=September 15, 2008|accessdate=September 24, 2008}}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
[[File:KateMara08TIFF.jpg|thumb|left|Mara at the [[2008 Toronto International Film Festival]] in September 2008]] In December 2008, Mara appeared in ''T Takes: Brooklyn 09'', a series of 6 improvised [[short film]]s directed by Brody Baker.<ref>"[https://www.nytimes.com/indexes/2008/12/07/style/t/index.html#pageName=tvideos5& T Takes]". ''[[T (New York Times)|T]]''. Retrieved on April 23, 2009.</ref> She starred in ''[[The Open Road]]'' as Lucy.<ref name="FraterFeb2008">Frater, Patrick (February 7, 2008). [http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117980406.html?categoryid=13&cs=1&nid=2562 Trio will hit 'Open Road']. ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]''. Retrieved on February 8, 2008.</ref> Filming began in [[Hammond, Louisiana]] in February 2008, and continued in [[Memphis, Tennessee]] and elsewhere in the [[southern United States|South]].<ref name="FraterFeb2008"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20181800,00.html|title=Justin Timberlake Shakes Up Southern Town|last=Lambert|first=Mark|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|date=March 4, 2008|accessdate=March 4, 2008}}</ref>
In 2009, Mara filmed the independent comedy ''[[Peep World]]'', starring [[Michael C. Hall]], [[Sarah Silverman]] and [[Rainn Wilson]],<ref name="Reuters-April2009">"[http://uk.reuters.com/article/peopleNews/idUKTRE53M0ZI20090423 Showbiz people briefs]". April 23, 2009. [[Reuters]]. Retrieved April 23, 2009.</ref> and joined the cast of [[Marvel Studios|Marvel]]'s ''[[Iron Man 2]]'', making a [[cameo appearance]] as a [[United States Marshals Service|U.S. Marshal]] who serves [[Tony Stark]] a subpoena.<ref>Marnell, Blair (January 7, 2010). "[http://splashpage.mtv.com/2010/01/07/war-machine-creator-says-iron-man-3-could-use-demon-in-a-bottle-story-debunks-iron-man-2-rumor "War Machine Creator Says 'Iron Man 3' Could Use 'Demon In A Bottle' Story, Debunks 'Iron Man 2' Rumor"]. [[MTV]]. Retrieved January 8, 2010.</ref> Mara shot the [[Ensemble film|ensemble]] romantic comedy ''[[Happy. Thank You. More. Please.]]'' in [[New York City]] in July 2009. She plays a waitress and aspiring singer named Mississippi, in a story about six single New Yorkers in their 20s. The film was written and directed by actor [[Josh Radnor]] (''[[How I Met Your Mother]]'').<ref name="NYPost-2009-07-12">"[http://www.nypost.com/seven/07122009/sports/moresports/the_rumble_178851.htm The Rumble]". July 12, 2009. ''New York Post''. Retrieved on July 12, 2009.</ref> The film won the U.S. Dramatic Audience Award at the 2010 [[Sundance Film Festival]].<ref name="reuters-2010-02"/> In 2010, Mara played hiker Kristi Moore in the survival drama ''[[127 Hours]]'', a true story directed by [[Danny Boyle]] about [[Aron Ralston]], a climber trapped while [[mountaineering]] in [[Utah]].<ref name="reuters-2010-02">Fernandez, Jay A.; & Kit, Borys (February 12, 2010). [https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE61B0TD20100212 "Kate Mara in talks for Boyle's '127 Hours'"]. [[Reuters]]. Retrieved February 12, 2010.</ref>
Mara appeared in ''[[Ironclad (film)|Ironclad]]'' (2011), which tells the story of the siege of [[Rochester Castle]] by [[John of England|King John]] in the year 1215.<ref>Woodrow, Emily (October 24, 2009). "[http://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/cardiff-news/2009/10/24/medieval-battle-scenes-in-the-valleywood-mud-91466-25002618/ Medieval battle scenes in the Valleywood mud] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121007211450/http://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/cardiff-news/2009/10/24/medieval-battle-scenes-in-the-valleywood-mud-91466-25002618/ |date=October 7, 2012 }}". ''[[South Wales Echo]]''. Retrieved on October 26, 2009.</ref> It is her first film where she speaks in an [[English language in England|English accent]].<ref>Medina, Marcy (April 6, 2010). "[http://www.wwd.com/lifestyle-news/eye/the-cast-of-indie-hopeful-happythankyoumoreplease-3023380 The Cast of Indie Hopeful 'HappyThankYouMorePlease]". ''[[Women's Wear Daily]]''. Retrieved on April 6, 2010.</ref> Mara appeared in the [[short film]] ''[[10 Years (2011 film)|Ten Year]]'', produced by [[Channing Tatum]] to attract financing for a feature film.<ref>Fleming, Mike (October 19, 2010). [http://www.deadline.com/2010/10/jamie-linden-and-channing-tatum-get-ten-year-feature-itch "Channing Tatum Has 'Ten Year' Feature Itch"]. ''[[Deadline Hollywood]]''. Retrieved October 20, 2010.</ref> The full-length feature went into production in [[Albuquerque]] in January 2010, with Mara starring in a large ensemble cast film about a 10-year high school reunion.<ref>[http://www.newswest9.com/Global/story.asp?S=13793011 'Ten Year' shooting begins in Albuquerque]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}. [[KWES-TV|KWES]]. [[Associated Press]]. January 6, 2011.</ref> In 2012, Mara starred in [[Stefan Ruzowitzky]]'s thriller ''[[Deadfall (2012 film)|Deadfall]]'' with [[Eric Bana]] and [[Olivia Wilde]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://arts.nationalpost.com/2011/04/16/eric-bana-can-be-whatever-you-need-him-to-be|title=Eric Bana can be whatever you need him to be|last=Thompson|first=Bob|work=[[National Post]]|date=April 16, 2011|accessdate=November 4, 2011|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120707104631/http://arts.nationalpost.com/2011/04/16/eric-bana-can-be-whatever-you-need-him-to-be/|archive-date=July 7, 2012|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/eric-bana-olivia-wilde-kate-395856|title=Eric Bana, Olivia Wilde, Kate Mara, Sissy Spacek and Kris Kristofferson take part in the intense dinner table scene for director Stefan Ruzowitzky's thriller|last=Chan|first=Stephanie|newspaper=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=November 30, 2012|accessdate=April 19, 2013}}</ref> In 2013, Mara starred in [[Broken Bells]] video for the song [[Holding On For Life]]. Mara appeared in ''[[Transcendence (2014 film)|Transcendence]]'' (2014), starring [[Johnny Depp]] and directed by [[Wally Pfister]].<ref>[https://variety.com/2013/film/news/kate-mara-boards-johnny-depp-project-transcendence-1200329644/ Kate Mara Boards Johnny Depp Project ‘Transcendence’], ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]].</ref>
In 2015, she played the [[Invisible Woman]] in a [[Fantastic Four (2015 film)|new film version]] of the [[Fantastic Four]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2014/film/news/miles-teller-kate-mara-fantastic-four-1201099921/|title=‘Fantastic Four’ Cast Revealed|last=Kroll|first=Justin|magazine=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=February 19, 2014|accessdate=February 20, 2014}}</ref> In that year, she also had a supporting role as astronaut Beth Johanssen in director [[Ridley Scott]]'s film ''[[The Martian (film)|The Martian]]''. She also starred as Ashley Smith in the 2015 movie ''[[Captive (2015 film)|Captive]]''.
In 2017, Mara starred in ''[[Megan Leavey (film)|Megan Leavey]]'', playing [[Megan Leavey]], a real life U.S. marine who bonded with her [[Dogs in warfare|military working dog]]. The film was directed by [[Gabriela Cowperthwaite]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/harry-potter-actor-tom-felton-833509|title='Harry Potter' Actor Tom Felton Joins Kate Mara in Indie War Hero Drama (Exclusive)|last=Kit|first=Borys|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=October 22, 2015|accessdate=October 22, 2015}}</ref> and released on June 9, 2017.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://variety.com/2017/film/news/megan-leavey-kate-mara-dog-1201958369/|title=Kate Mara Iraq War Hero Biopic ‘Megan Leavey’ Gets Release Date|last=McNary|first=Dave|date=January 11, 2017|newspaper=Variety|language=en-US|access-date=January 11, 2017}}</ref>
She also starred alongside [[Ellen Page]] in ''[[My Days of Mercy]]'', which she co-produced.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2016/film/news/ellen-page-kate-mara-romance-mercy-exclusive-1201840449/|title=Tali Shalom Ezer Directing Ellen Page and Kate Mara in Romantic Drama ‘Mercy’|website=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|first=Dave|last=McNary|date=August 18, 2016|accessdate=January 13, 2017}}</ref>
==Personal life== In late 2015, Mara began dating her ''[[Fantastic Four (2015 film)|Fantastic Four]]'' co-star [[Jamie Bell]]<ref>{{cite web|last1=Nessif|first1=Bruna|title=Jamie Bell Says He's Not Engaged to Girlfriend Kate Mara Despite Her Ring on That Finger|url=http://www.eonline.com/news/745517/jamie-bell-says-he-s-not-engaged-to-girlfriend-kate-mara-despite-her-ring-on-that-finger|website=[[E!]]}}</ref> and in January 2017, the couple got engaged.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.moviefone.com/2017/01/13/fantastic-four-co-stars-kate-mara-and-jamie-bell-get-engaged/|title='Fantastic Four' Co-Stars Kate Mara and Jamie Bell Get Engaged|first=Kelly|last=Woo|work=moviefone|date=January 13, 2017|accessdate=January 13, 2017}}</ref> On July 17, 2017, the couple announced that they had married.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://people.com/movies/kate-mara-and-jamie-bell-tie-the-knot-in-surprise-ceremony/|title= Kate Mara and Jamie Bell Tie the Knot in Surprise Ceremony|first=Mike|last=Miller|work=People|date=July 17, 2017|accessdate=July 17, 2017}}</ref> Mara is stepmother to Bell's son from his marriage to [[Evan Rachel Wood]].
Mara currently lives in [[Los Angeles]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://modernluxury.com/manhattan/story/lady-luck |title=After an eye-catching turn on the Netflix hit House of Cards, Kate Mara has a few more tricks up her sleeve |work=Modernluxury.com |accessdate=October 30, 2014}}</ref> and [[Manhattan]].<ref name=tdstree>{{cite news|url=http://www.thedailytruffle.com/2012/02/rooney-mara-football-family |title=ROONEY MARA FAMILY TREE |newspaper=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette |date=February 4, 2012 |accessdate=February 9, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120208203017/http://www.thedailytruffle.com/2012/02/rooney-mara-football-family/ |archivedate=February 8, 2012 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://twitter.com/KateMara |title=Kate Mara verified Twitter Account |work=[[Twitter]] |accessdate=October 30, 2014}}</ref> She credits her [[vegan diet]] and regular workouts for keeping herself fit.<ref>Jennifer Chan, "[http://www.eonline.com/news/491723/what-s-trending-with-kate-mara-orlane-skin-care-bar-method-workouts-and-more What's Trending with Kate Mara: Orlane Skin Care, Bar Method Workouts and More]," EOnline, December 17, 2013.</ref> "I'm a massive animal lover, too," she explained. "Being vegan has been so good for me. I've never felt better."<ref>{{cite news|title=House of Cards' Kate Mara: 'It is complicated being compared to my sister Rooney'|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/house-of-cards-kate-mara-it-is-complicated-being-compared-to-my-sister-kate-rooney-9281446.html|last=Pringle|first=Gill|newspaper=[[The Independent]]|date=April 25, 2014|accessdate=June 8, 2015}}</ref>
Mara has stated she comes from a "huge" family;<ref name="WFAN"/> her father is one of 11 children, and she has 22 aunts and uncles and 40 cousins.<ref name="Longsdorf"/><ref>Schwartz, Paul. [http://www.nypost.com/p/sports/emotion_was_right_potion_fueled_ylHvGL4xkx4IdygnPGNRrM "Emotion Was Right Potion – Fueled by Mara, Giants Blank Redskins"], ''[[New York Post]]'', October 31, 2005</ref> As a descendant of the owners of the New York Giants and Pittsburgh Steelers, Mara is a fan of both teams;<ref name="Vanities">Smith, Krista (September 2006). "[http://www.vanityfair.com/culture/features/2007/05/vanities_portfolio200705#slide=31 The Vanities Girls: Kara Mara]". ''[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]''. Retrieved July 12, 2007.</ref><ref>Tucker, Reed (January 8, 2009). "[http://www.nypost.com/seven/01082009/entertainment/pigskin_princesses_149103.htm Kate and Rooney Mara Are Pigskin Princesses]". ''New York Post''. Retrieved April 23, 2009.</ref> she joked, "If I'm mad at my mom I root for the Giants, and if I'm pissed at my dad I root for the Steelers."<ref name="kimmel">{{cite episode | series=Jimmy Kimmel Live | url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kXwyat947aU | network=ABC | airdate=April 9, 2014 |title=Tracy Morgan, Kate Mara, Birds of Tokyo}}</ref> This relationship contributed to her being cast in ''We Are Marshall''.{{r|anderson20061225}} Mara has sung at both teams' games,<ref name="Newsday"/><ref>Alt, Eric (May 2006). "Kate Mara". ''[[Nylon Magazine]]''.</ref> and after missing the Steelers' 2006 victory at [[Super Bowl XL]] due to work, her contracts now state that she can attend if either team goes to the Super Bowl.<ref name=anderson20061225>{{cite news|url=http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/06359/748291-66.stm|title=Rooney connection brings Kate Mara to Pittsburgh|last=Anderson|first=Shelly|newspaper=[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]|date=December 25, 2006|accessdate=February 7, 2011}}</ref> She was in attendance for the Giants' victory in [[Super Bowl XLII]], the Steelers' victory the next year in [[Super Bowl XLIII]], and the Giants' victory in [[Super Bowl XLVI]].
Mara is one of the faces of the [[Humane Society of the United States]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.humanesociety.org/news/press_releases/2015/01/celebs-support-prop-2-010515.html|title=Kate Mara, Nikki Reed, Ian Somerhalder and Moby Celebrate New Farm Animal Protection Laws|work=[[The Humane Society of the United States]]|date=January 5, 2015|accessdate=March 25, 2015}}</ref> In 2015, she was featured in one of their campaign videos to promote [[Meatless Monday]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.humanesociety.org/wayne/2015/03/kate-mara-hsus-video.html |title=Is Industrialized Agriculture a House of Cards? |author=[[Wayne Pacelle]] |work=The Humane Society of the United States |date=March 2, 2015 |accessdate=March 25, 2015}}</ref>

{{Infobox person | name = Kay Robertson | image = Kay Robertson by Gage Skidmore.jpg | caption = Kay Robertson in 2015. | birth_name = Marsha Kay Carroway | birth_date = December 21, 1947 (age 70) | birth_place = [[West Monroe, Louisiana]], U.S. | alias = Miss Kay | television = ''[[Duck Dynasty]]'' | occupation = Television personality | spouse = {{marriage|[[Phil Robertson]]|1966}} | children = Marshal Alan Robertson
[[Jase Robertson|Jason Silas Robertson]]
[[Willie Robertson|Willie Jess Robertson]]
Jules Jeptha Robertson | residence = West Monroe, Louisiana | years_active = 2012–present }} '''Marsha Kay Carroway Robertson''',Date and year of birth disputed. Sources cite December 21, 1950, others cite July 3, 1951, still others cite 1947 as her year of birth.{{cite news|last=Pantiss|first=Sonia|title=Duck Dynasty stars: Miss Kay Robertson|url=http://www.bellenews.com/?p=35804|newspaper=Belle News|date=June 5, 2013}} also known as '''Miss Kay''', is an American television personality, best known for her appearances on the [[A&E (TV channel)|A&E]] [[reality television|reality series]] ''[[Duck Dynasty]]''. Robertson is the wife of [[entrepreneur]] and ''Duck Dynasty'' co-star [[Phil Robertson]], and mother of ''Duck Dynasty'' personality and current [[Duck Commander]] [[CEO]] [[Willie Robertson]]. She is commonly referred to on the show as "Miss Kay". She has a passion for cooking.{{cite web|url=http://www.aetv.com/duck-dynasty/meet-family/miss-kay-robertson|title=Miss Kay Robertson – Duck Dynasty Cast|publisher=AEtv.com|accessdate=2012-06-16}}Hill, Erin (November 23, 2013) [http://www.parade.com/231229/erinhill "Duck Dynasty's Miss Kay on Her Love of Cooking and Family Values"], Parade.com; retrieved December 2, 2013. She is the author of the cookbook ''Miss Kay's Duck Commander Kitchen: Faith, Family, and Food--Bringing Our Home to Your Table''.[http://www.patriotledger.com/community/blogs/food-for-thought/x2132754352/Duck-Dynasty-cookbook "'Duck Dynasty' cookbook"], ''The Patriot Ledger'', November 16, 2013; retrieved December 2, 2013. ==Personal life== In high school, Kay was a cheerleader and a [[debutante]].[http://girlsjustwannahaveguns.com/2014/01/throwback-mrs-duck-dynasty-reveals-fascinating-pictures-teen-cheerleader-class-beauty Profile], girlsjustwannahaveguns.com; accessed November 20, 2015. Kay and Phil Robertson began dating in 1964 and married two years later.{{cite web|url=https://tv.yahoo.com/news/duck-dynasty--couples--how-they-met-234103918.html|title=How Did the 'Duck Dynasty' Couples Meet?|date=April 16, 2013|accessdate=January 6, 2014|author=Woo, Kelly}} Some sources claim she was 16 at the time of her marriage, others indicate she was 17 when she gave birth to her first child, Alan.[http://dailyentertainmentnews.com/tv/kay-carroway-robertson-duck-dynasty-phil-robertsons-wife Profile], dailyentertainmentnews.com; accessed November 20, 2015. They have four sons: Alan, [[Jase Robertson|Jase]], [[Willie Robertson|Willie]], and Jep, as well as sixteen grandchildren and several great-grandchildren.{{cite web|last=Takeda|first=Allison|url=http://www.usmagazine.com/entertainment/news/duck-dynastys-phil-robertson-miss-kay-open-up-about-pre-fame-infidelity-alcohol-issues-in-new-film-20132011|title=Duck Dynasty's Phil, Miss Kay Talk Infidelity, Alcoholism in New Film|publisher=Usmagazine.com|date=2013-11-20|accessdate=2014-01-02}}{{cite web|url=http://www.christianpost.com/news/duck-dynasty-stars-phil-miss-kay-how-jesus-christ-saved-their-marriage-restored-their-family-96101|title='Duck Dynasty' Stars Phil, Miss Kay: How Jesus Christ Saved Their Marriage, Restored Their Family |publisher=Christianpost.com|date=2013-05-18|accessdate=2014-01-02}} ==Bibliography== *''Miss Kay's Duck Commander Kitchen: Faith, Family, and Food – Bringing Our Home to Your Table'' (co-written with Chrys Howard). [[Simon & Schuster]]. (2013); {{ISBN|9781476763200}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Duck Commander}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Robertson, Kay}} [[Category:1947 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American cookbook writers]] [[Category:American debutantes]] [[Category:Participants in American reality television series]] [[Category:American members of the Churches of Christ]] [[Category:Robertson family]] [[Category:Women cookbook writers]] [[Category:Age controversies]] [[Category:American women non-fiction writers]] {{US-tv-bio-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} '''Labour battalions''' have been a form of [[alternative service]] or [[unfree labour]] in various countries in lieu of or resembling regular [[military service]]. In some cases they were the result of some kind of [[discrimination|discriminative]] segregation of the population, while in some others they have been a conscious choice.
==Political reasons== In some countries labour battalions were created from part of population which for various reasons were not suitable for regular military service, often because this population was considered "undesirable" or "unreliable", e.g., political enemies, population of occupied territories or "lower [[Race (classification of human beings)|races]]".
Examples include labour battalions in the late [[Ottoman Empire]] and early [[Turkish Republic]] both [[Labour Battalions (Ottoman Empire)|during World War I]] and [[The Twenty Classes|during World War II]], [[labour service (Hungary)|labour service in Hungary during World War II]], as well as labour battalions in other territories held by [[Nazi Germany]] and its allies (see also "[[Hiwi (volunteer)|Hiwi]]".).
==Alternative service== In some countries labour battalions are a form of alternative [[conscription]] for people who cannot join military service for various reasons, e.g., due to bad health or being [[conscientious objector]]s to any forms of violence.
Until the last days of the [[Soviet Union]] with obligatory military duty in the state, men deemed unfit to regular military duty, as well as many able-bodied ones, were assigned to ''[[construction battalion (Soviet Union)|construction battalion]]s'' (стройбаты) of the [[Soviet Army]] .
==See also== * [[Bevin Boys]] in the [[United Kingdom]] from 1943 to 1948 * [[Construction soldier|Bausoldat]] in [[East Germany]] * [[Civilian Conservation Corps]] as a public [[work relief program]] in the [[United States]] from 1933 to 1942 * [[Labor army|Labour army]] * [[Labor camp|Labour camp]] * [[Reichsarbeitsdienst]] in [[Nazi Germany]] from 1933 to 1945
{{DEFAULTSORT:Labour Battalion}} [[Category:Unfree labour]] [[Category:Conscription]] [[Category:Non-combatant military personnel]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2017}} {{Multiple issues| {{orphan|date=April 2010}} {{notability|date=April 2010}} {{advert|date=April 2010}} }}
The '''market contact audit''' is a research tool, which measures the effectiveness of various contacts in a category using a common method and a common unit.<ref>{{cite web|author=Palgrave Macmillan Journals |url=http://www.palgrave-journals.com/jmm/journal/v7/n4/abs/5050100a.html |title=Journals formerly published by Palgrave Macmillan: Palgrave Macmillan Journals |publisher=Palgrave-journals.com |date= |accessdate=2012-02-14}}</ref> Therefore, it provides a yardstick to understand which are the key contacts that drive the category, which contact points are working better for the brand and which are the ones where money should be saved. It is a planning process that helps in rationalizing and prioritizing the marketing and media spends.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.integration-imc.com/WhatIsMCA.asp |title=Integration – About the MCA – What Is The MCA-Marketing Information System? |publisher=Integration-imc.com |date= |accessdate=2012-02-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120301171637/http://www.integration-imc.com/WhatIsMca.asp |archivedate=1 March 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
The market contact audit measures how successfully brands use marketing communications to connect with consumers in two ways. First it recognizes that some contacts are more influential than others. So it measures the Contact Clout Factor – or contact influence for the important contacts in a given category and market.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.integration-imc.com/Insead%20validation%20report.pdf |accessdate=21 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061016013742/http://www.integration-imc.com/Insead%20validation%20report.pdf |archivedate=16 October 2006 }}</ref> Then it recognizes that some brands execute better than others, so it measures brand experience for each brand in the category and market, by the degree to which consumers recall encountering brands in a contact.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.accessmylibrary.com/article-1G1-138667189/managing-brand-experience-market.html |title=Article: Managing brand experience: the Market Contact Audit[TM]. | AccessMyLibrary – Promoting library advocacy |publisher=AccessMyLibrary |date=1 March 2005 |accessdate=2012-02-14}}</ref>
==Outline of the MCA research method== In summary, via consumers' interviews, using [[Monadic Testing|monadic]] cards each with a contact description in consumer language, two interview techniques are used to ascertain the three intrinsic values of contacts for a given [[product category]] and [[Market (economics)|market]]:
* The "process of elimination" is used to develop the Information and Attractive Values of contacts to ascertain their cognitive and emotive influence,<ref>The New Positioning, by Jack Trout and Steve Rivkin, McGraw-Hill, 1996</ref> * The contacts that are high in either Information or Attractive Value, or both, is then rank-ordered by their importance using the "Just Noticeable Difference" system. This ascertains their Power Value, or their behavioral influence,<ref>Thurston, 1927</ref>
The survey asks consumers to associate Brands competing in the category with the screened contacts to measure the perceived weight of brands' activities relative to competition. (The questionnaire takes approximately 25 minutes in face-to-face interviews, and has been validated across a variety of [[fieldwork]] techniques – from face to face to self-administered on-line questionnaire. The questionnaire is well suited to be included in standard brand surveys such as U&A, Awareness and Image studies, etc. and relate them to the universe of contact).
In 1998 the MCA cethod was widened by the discovery of a way to merge the three [[Intrinsic value (ethics)|intrinsic value]]s of a contact into a single indicator, via a series of [[algorithm]]s. The merging of the three values into one generates a new indicator, the Contact Clout Factor (CCF).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://s3.amazonaws.com/thearf-org-aux-assets/downloads/research/ARF_Review_Integration_MCA.pdf |title=ARF : The Research Authority : First Opinion |publisher=S3.amazon.com |accessdate=2013-11-02}}</ref>
The CCF score indicates the effectiveness of a contact by its capacity to influence attitudes relative to the other contacts screened.
Besides permitting the prioritization of contacts by their measured effectiveness, the CCF also enables the creation of a currency for the comparison of effectiveness and competitiveness of Brand Activities.
==Output==
=== Brand experience points (BEPS) === Brand experience points (BEP) is an indicator that reflects the perceived weight of experienced consumer – brand encounters through individual contacts. BEPs are measured by the degree to which consumers associate brands and contacts. These associations are normalized and weighted by the CCF to deliver the BEP levels for each brand against each contact.<ref>First Opinion: An Advertising Research Foundation Research Review of Integration Marketing & Communications Limited’s Market ContactAudit Methodology William A. Cook, Ph.D., Sr. V.P., Research & Standards 20 February 2007</ref>
The higher the BEP level for a contact, the more consumers report experiencing the brand in that contact.
The brand contact BEP accounts for the contribution of the brand perceived activity to the overall brand experience. BEP takes into account quantity (level of association of the brand with the contact) and [[Quality (business)|quality]] (association weighted by the respective influence of the contact). Hence an association of 40% on a most influential contact (as rated by consumers) has a clearly different contribution to building brand experience than 40% scored on a less influential contact. Through BEPs, which are weighted via the CCF, activities can be compared across all brands and among all contacts of the category. Through BEPs, levels of activities can also be compared across markets and categories.
Substantial disparities have been noted in the average levels of BEPs among leaders across categories and markets: The average level of BEP of leaders can range from 500 to 3,000. These disparities are the result of i) different levels of consumer receptiveness; ii) the degree of competitiveness in the category; iii) the type of the category: fragmented (lower levels of BEP) as opposed to fewer brand players (higher levels of BEP).
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} {{Infobox officeholder |name = Mary Ellen Iskenderian |image = Mary Ellen Iskenderian Headshot.jpg |office = President and CEO of [[Women's World Banking]] |term_start = |term_end = |predecessor = |successor = }} {{ad|date=March 2015}} '''Mary Ellen Iskenderian''' is President and CEO of [[Women's World Banking]], the world’s largest network of microfinance institutions and banks.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.telegram.com/article/20100113/APF/301139849/1002/business |title=Gates Foundation allocates $38M in banking grants |date=13 January 2010 |work=Worcester Telegram & Gazette |accessdate=28 July 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5rZ7meXGR?url=http://www.telegram.com/article/20100113/APF/301139849/1002/business |archivedate=28 July 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
Iskenderian leads Women's World Banking's global team, based in [[New York City]], in providing technical services and strategic support to 39 microfinance institutions and banks in 27 countries in [[Africa]], [[Asia]], [[Eastern Europe]], [[Latin America]] and the [[Middle East]].<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.womensworldbanking.org/about-us/what-we-do/ |title=What We Do | Women's World Banking |publisher=Womensworldbanking.org |date= |accessdate=2014-02-02}}</ref> Iskenderian joined the organization in 2006.
Iskenderian has more than 20 years of experience in building [[global financial system]]s throughout the developing world. She is a strong advocate for moving [[microfinance]] beyond credit by providing low-income women with a full suite of financial products and services and a proponent for the role of responsible investment in the microfinance sector. Iskenderian has spoken widely on microfinance at [[Harvard University|Harvard]], [[Yale University|Yale]], [[Stanford University|Stanford]] and [[Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania|Wharton]] and at numerous industry and banking forums including the annual conference of [[Cercle des économistes]], the [[Council on Foreign Relations]], the [[Inter-American Development Bank|IDB]] Foromic and the [[Microcredit Summit Campaign|Microcredit Summit]]. She has been published in [[Forbes|Forbes magazine]] and [[The Wall Street Journal]];<ref>{{cite web|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/source/2011/07/24/five-lessons-for-the-microfinance-industry/ |title=Five Lessons for the Microfinance Industry - The Source - WSJ |publisher=Blogs.wsj.com |date=2011-07-24 |accessdate=2014-02-02}}</ref> is a regular contributor to the [[Harvard Business Review]] blog; and is frequently quoted in the media, including the [[Financial Times]], Newsweek, Time, BBC News and the Atlantic.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/2008/11/06/040d.html |title=Thinking Big-and Small: Mary Ellen Iskenderian |publisher=Forbes |date= |accessdate=2014-02-02}}</ref>
Prior to joining Women's World Banking, Iskenderian was a senior manager at the [[International Finance Corporation]] of the [[World Bank Group]] and held leadership positions including Director of Partnership Development, Director of Global Financial Markets Portfolio and Director of the South Asia Regional Department. She currently serves on the Board of Directors of Kashf Microfinance Bank in Pakistan and is a permanent member of the [[Council on Foreign Relations]]. She serves as an Advisor to the [[Clinton Global Initiative]] and is a judge for the annual Financial Times Sustainable Banking Awards. She was also recently invited by Secretary of State [[Hillary Clinton]] to be a member of the US delegation to the [[APEC United States 2011|Asia-Pacific Economic Conference (APEC) 2011]] Women and the Economy Summit.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gender.go.jp/kaigi/renkei/ikenkoukan/50/pdf/ref05.pdf |title=APEC Women and the Economy Summit |publisher=Gender.go.jp |accessdate=2014-02-02}}</ref> Iskenderian is a past recipient of [[New York University Stern School of Business|NYU Stern]]’s Distinguished Citi Fellowship in Leadership and Ethics,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stern.nyu.edu/experience-stern/news-events/UAT_024051 |title=NYU Stern | News | NYU Stern’s Citi Leadership & Ethics Program Selects Mary Ellen Iskenderian as Distinguished Fellow |publisher=Stern.nyu.edu |date=2009-11-12 |accessdate=2014-02-02}}</ref> the Isabel Benham Award from the Women’s Bond Club, and the companion Women’s Finance Award given by the Institute of Financial Services at [[Lucerne University of Applied Sciences and Arts|Lucerne University]], [[Switzerland]]. Previously, she worked for the investment bank [[Lehman Brothers]].
Iskenderian holds an [[MBA]] from the [[Yale School of Management]] and a [[Bachelor of Science|B.S.]] in International Economics from the [[Georgetown University School of Foreign Service]].

Walsh School of Foreign Service alumni]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Yale University alumni]] [[Category:World Bank Group people]]

Manhattan, New York
Aspen, Colorado | nationality =American | other_names = | known_for = | education = | employer = | occupation =Philanthropist, Socialite | title = | salary = | networth = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party =Republican | boards =[[Carnegie Hall Corporation]], [[Aspen Institute]], [[Fort Worth Symphony Orchestra]], [[Metropolitan Opera]], [[American Academy in Rome]] | religion = | spouse =[[Francis L. Kellogg]] (divorced)
[[Sid Bass]] (divorced) | children = | parents =[[Abolhassan Diba]] (step-father)
Sorure Tavacoli-Diba (mother) | relatives = [[Farah Pahlavi]] (step-cousin) [[Mohammad Mosaddegh]] (step-uncle) | box_width = }} '''Mercedes Bass''' (born Mercedes Tavacoli) is an Iranian-American philanthropist and socialite active in [[New York City]], [[Aspen, Colorado]] and [[Fort Worth, Texas]]. She has supported the [[Metropolitan Opera]] and she is a trustee of the [[Aspen Institute]] and the [[American Academy in Rome]]. ==Early life== Mercedes Tavacoli Diba was born in [[Iran]] in 1944 to an upper-class family.Eric Wilson, [https://www.nytimes.com/2011/10/16/fashion/the-marriage-of-sid-and-mercedes-bass-now-broken.html?pagewanted=all An ’80s Scandal Comes to a Quiet End], ''[[The New York Times]]'', October 14, 2011Maureen Callahan, [https://nypost.com/2011/10/16/the-story-behind-sid-mercedes-bass-affair-marriage-and-surprising-split/ The story behind Sid & Mercedes Bass' affair, marriage and surprising split], ''[[The New York Post]]'', October 16, 2011 She was educated in [[England]].{{cite web|url=http://www.aspeninstitute.org/people/mercedes-bass|title=Mercedes Bass - The Aspen Institute|publisher=}} She received a bachelor's degree in Business from a [[Switzerland|Swiss]] university. Her father died when she was young. Her mother Sorure Tavacoli subsequently married [[Abolhassan Diba]]. He was the son of Fazlollah Diba (an aide to Crown Prince [[Mozaffar ad-Din Shah Qajar]]) and Princess Malektadj Firuz (great-granddaughter of [[Fath-Ali Shah Qajar]], second Qajar King (Shah) of Persia). She is a step-cousin of [[Farah Pahlavi]], former Empress of Iran. Her step-father was also the half-brother of former Iranian prime minister [[Mohammad Mosaddegh]]. {{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pOcCAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA48&lpg=PA48&dq=mercedes+kellogg&source=bl&ots=lPjrQDmxgF&sig=8pPNat2UL4_cnOZqrTRgLgtvgTY&hl=en&sa=X&sqi=2&ved=0ahUKEwjPnOaxroXMAhWl2aYKHU7dD1cQ6AEIXDAN#v=onepage&q=mercedes+kellogg&f=false|title=New York Magazine|first=New York Media|last=LLC|date=20 October 1986|publisher=New York Media, LLC|via=Google Books}} ==Philanthropy== She serves as Vice Chairman of the Board of Trustees and the Executive Committee of the [[Carnegie Hall|Carnegie Hall Corporation]] as well as Managing Director of the Board of Trustees and Executive Board of the [[Metropolitan Opera]], both of which are based in [[New York City]].{{cite web|url=http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=7700938&privcapId=6547850&previousCapId=21401&previousTitle=KKR+&+CO+LP|title=Mercedes T. Bass: Executive Profile & Biography - Bloomberg|website=investing.businessweek.com}} In 2008, she appeared as an extra at the Met.Haven Thompson, [http://www.wmagazine.com/people/celebrities/2008/04/mercedes-at-the-met/ Mercedes at the Met], ''[[W (magazine)|W]]'', April 2008 In 2006 she donated $25 million to the [[Metropolitan Opera]]. The Mercedes T Bass Grand Tier was subsequently named in her honour.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Q0xKykLbrHQ|title=mercedes_dedication.AVI|first=|last=SBAdventures|date=23 April 2011|publisher=|via=YouTube}} Additionally, she serves on the Advisory Board of the [[Aspen Music School]] and on the Board of Trustees of the [[Aspen Institute]], both of which are based in [[Aspen, Colorado]].Brent Gardner-Smith, [http://www.aspendailynews.com/section/home/aspen-and-forbes-400 Aspen and the Forbes 400 list], ''[[Aspen Daily News]]'', September 28, 2007 She has also served as Vice Chairman of the Executive Committee and member of the Board of Directors of the [[Fort Worth Symphony Orchestra|Fort Worth Symphony Orchestra Association]] in [[Fort Worth, Texas]], where she has been a donor.[http://www.star-telegram.com/2014/02/20/5583829/fort-worth-symphony-orchestra.html Fort Worth Symphony Orchestra forms ‘artistic partnership’ with Cliburn winner Kholodenko], ''[[Fort Worth Star-Telegram]]'', February 20, 2014 Currently, she serves as this orchestra's Chairman of the Board.{{cite web|url=http://www.fwsymphony.org/about/board.asp|title=Fort Worth Symphony Orchestra ::: Board|website=www.fwsymphony.org}} She serves as Vice Chairman of the Executive Committee and member of the Board of Trustees of the [[American Academy in Rome]] in [[Rome]], [[Italy]]. In 2013, she chaired the gala of the Rome Prize.Amanda Gordon, [https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-04-18/scene-last-night-bass-fetes-rome-muse-tory-burch.html Scene Last Night: Bass Fetes Rome Muse; Tory Burch], ''[[Bloomberg BusinessWeek]]'', April 19, 2013 In 2012, she was a donor to [[Rick Perry]]'s presidential campaign.Anna M.Tinsley, [http://www.star-telegram.com/2012/11/03/4386422/texas-donors-pour-61-million-into.html Texas donors pour $61 million into election], ''[[Fort Worth Star-Telegram]]'', November 4, 2012 In 2014, she was the underwriter of the [[Oscar de la Renta]] exhibition at the [[George W. Bush Presidential Center]] in [[Dallas, Texas]].Christina Geyer, [http://www.dallasnews.com/news/community-news/park-cities/headlines/20140718-bush-center-displays-oscar-de-la-renta-originals.ece Bush Presidential Center displays Oscar de la Renta originals], ''[[The Dallas Morning News]]'', July 18, 2014 She is also a donor to the Republican National Committee and Donald Trump's presidential campaign.[http://www.star-telegram.com/news/politics-government/article82971572.html Fort Worth Star-Telegram] ==Personal life== She came to America as a friend and protégé of automotive heir [[Henry Buhl]]. Her first husband, Ambassador [[Francis L. Kellogg]], served as a Special Assistant to Secretaries of State [[William P. Rogers]] and [[Henry Kissinger]]. They met while she was working as an executive assistant to a UN official. They married in Geneva, Switzerland, on October 12, 1972. The Mayor of Geneva performed the ceremony. [[Ardeshir Zahedi]] was Kellogg's best man and the Shah's personal emissary at the ceremony.{{cite web|url=http://archives.chicagotribune.com/1972/10/14/page/N_A26/article/cream-of-the-crop|title=Cream of the Crop (October 14, 1972)|publisher=}} They lived in an apartment at 775 Park Avenue and maintained an estate in Bedford, New York. In June 1986, at the 'Black and White Ball' hosted by the Duke of Marlborough at Blenheim Palace, she first met Texas billionnaire Sid Bass. They met again at a Bastille Day party in the Hamptons several weeks later where she caught his attention by throwing a bread roll in his direction. In September 1986 their relationship became public when socialite Sao Schlumberger saw them walking hand-in-hand at the Hotel Plaza Athenee in Paris. She divorced Kellogg and married [[Sid Bass]] on December 10, 1988 at New York's Plaza Hotel. In January 1990 they purchased four adjacent properties on Fort Worth's Crestline Road, overlooking the Trinity River valley. Two houses were combined into one large mansion, a third was razed after representatives of charitable causes pried loose all salvageable paneling and plumbing from the premises, and the fourth property was transported across town to the grounds of the Lena Pope Home for Troubled Children. When she discovered that the house across the street could see over the fence into their house, she had Sid buy that house too. It was transported to his brother's ranch. They divorced in 2011.[https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/reliable-source/post/love-etc-sid-and-mercedes-bass-divorce/2011/10/10/gIQAr5sSaL_blog.html Love, etc.: Sid and Mercedes Bass divorce], ''[[The Washington Post]]'', 10/10/2011 Following the divorce, their 26-acre estate 'Oak Hill' on Crestline Road Fort Worth, their Aspen home and apartment at 845 Fifth Avenue in New York were all transferred to her.{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20117575,00.html|title=Cover Story: Marriage with a Midas Touch – Vol. 33 No. 18|date=7 May 1990|publisher=}}{{cite book|last1=LLC|first1=New York Media|title=New York Magazine|date=1986|publisher=New York Media, LLC|page=52|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pOcCAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA52|language=en}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bass, Mercedes}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Iranian emigrants to the United States]] [[Category:People from New York City]] [[Category:People from Fort Worth, Texas]] [[Category:People from Aspen, Colorado]] [[Category:Philanthropists from New York (state)]] [[Category:Metropolitan Opera people]] [[Category:Bass family]] [[Category:1944 births]]

revision.text:
'''Michael A. Fyshe''' is a Canadian management consultant, advertising executive and former President and CEO for [[BBDO]] Canada.<ref>{{Cite magazine|url = |title = Top 200 CEOs|last = |first = |date = November 1998|magazine=The Financial Post Magazine, CEO Annual 1998|doi = |pmid = |access-date = |page =64}}</ref><ref>{{Cite magazine|url =http://search.proquest.com/docview/205862578?accountid=14369 |title = Canada's Corporate Elite 1999|last = |first = |date = November 1999|magazine=[[National Post Business (Magazine)|National Post Business]], Special Issue|doi = |pmid = |access-date = |page =76|registration = Yes}}</ref>
Fyshe was born in Montreal, Quebec in 1947, and attended [[Trinity College School]]<ref>{{Cite book|title = Trinity College School Record, Vol 66. No 1 (December 1963- August 1964)|last = |first = |publisher = |year = 1965|isbn = |location = }}</ref> in Port Hope, Ontario. He gained his first experience in advertising when he worked as a Production Manager at Montreal luxury department store, [[Ogilvy (department store)|Ogilvy’s]]. After senior positions at Toronto advertising agencies, MacLaren McCann, Vickers & Benson and Young & Rubicam, he joined BBDO Canada in 1990 as Executive Vice President leading the Chrysler account.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url = http://strategyonline.ca/2001/02/26/moversshakers-20010226/|title = Movers & Shakers|date = February 26, 2001|accessdate = |website = http://strategyonline.ca/|publisher = Brunico|last = |first = }}</ref> In 1996 he became President and COO of the agency's successful retail division, BBDO Retail, which served clients such as [[Dairy Queen]], [[Talbots]], [[The Sports Network|TSN]] and [[Molson]].<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://strategyonline.ca/1996/11/11/12797-19961111/|title = BBDO’s Tolpin heads south: Creet, McLaughlin named co-creative directors|date = November 11, 1996|accessdate = |website = http://strategyonline.ca/|publisher = Brunico|last = |first = }}</ref> When he stepped down in 2001, Fyshe had been serving as President and CEO of BBDO Canada since 1997.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite magazine|url =http://search.proquest.com/docview/227208069?accountid=14369 |title = Fyshe takes the spotlight as BBDO CEO|last = Lara|first = Mills|date = December 8, 1997|magazine=Marketing Magazine|doi = |pmid = |access-date = |publisher = Rogers Publishing Ltd|page =2|registration = Yes}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url = http://adage.com/article/news/fyshe-leaves-bbdo-canada/29085/|title = Fyshe leaves BBDO Canada|date = February 16, 2001|accessdate = |website = adage.com|publisher = Crain Communications Inc.|last = |first = }}</ref>
Fyshe is well known for his work with two of his major clients, automotive giants Ford of Canada and [[Chrysler Canada]]. At Vickers & Benson, Fyshe was responsible for forming a team recognized by Ford of Canada as the strongest that they had worked with in the 30 years that Vickers & Benson had managed the Lincoln and Mercury brand business. During his tenure at BBDO Retail, his team developed a number of popular Chrysler commercials that included "Snowball", part of a campaign that was picked up around the world and won several awards including the 1997 'Canadian Advertising Success Stories' ([http://cassies.ca/ Cassies]) Grand Prix.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://cassies.ca/content/caselibrary/winners/ChryslerMinivans.pdf|title = Chrysler Minivans: The New Originals. The Launch of the 1996 NS Series.|date = 1997|accessdate = |website = http://cassies.ca/|publisher = |last = |first = |format = PDF}}</ref> The work helped Chrysler solidify their position as the leading manufacturer of [[Chrysler S platform|Minivans in Canada]] with unprecedented sales volume.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://strategyonline.ca/1997/11/10/19791-19971110/|title = BBDO cops three Golds at Cassies|date = November 10, 1997|accessdate = |website = http://strategyonline.ca/|publisher = Brunico Communications|last = |first = }}</ref> While President and CEO at BBDO Canada, he built and led a team that went on to win numerous new business pitches and creative awards, and saw the agency recognized as ''the'' creative power house in Canada at the time.<ref>{{Cite journal|url =http://search.proquest.com/docview/1147250468?accountid=14369 |title = BBDO Back In the saddle again|last = John|first = Heinzl|date = November 23, 1998|journal = Globe and Mail, Report on Business|doi = |pmid = |access-date = |page =B15|registration = Yes}}</ref>
In 2000 Fyshe and Neale Halliday, then the BBDO Canada's EVP, Head of Account Planning, initiated the first BBDO Brand Camp, an observational research concept developed to measure consumer behavior.<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/welcome-to-brand-camp-kids-part-survivor-part-focus-group/article4168189/|title = Welcome to brand camp, kids: part Survivor, part focus group|date = October 12, 2000|accessdate = |website = https://www.theglobeandmail.com/|publisher = The Globe and Mail|last = Heinzl|first = John}}</ref>
After stepping down at BBDO Canada in 2001,<ref>{{Cite magazine|url =http://search.proquest.com/docview/227172756?accountid=14369 |title = A Fyshe out of water|last = Lara|first = Mills|date = May 7, 2001|magazine=Marketing Magazine|doi = |pmid = |access-date = |publisher = Rogers Publishing Ltd|page =7|registration = Yes}}</ref> he formed [http://www.reynoldsandfyshe.com/ Reynolds & Fyshe], a niche marketing management consulting practice with Dan Reynolds, focused on improving the value of agency services delivery and agency search & selection.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.reynoldsandfyshe.com/|title = Reynolds & Fyshe|date = Jan 28, 2015|accessdate = |website = Reynolds & Fyshe|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url = http://news.thelistonline.com/featured/ask-an-ad-agency-search-consultant-how-to-form-enduring-client-agency-relationships/|title = Ask An Agency Search Consultant: How to form enduring client-agency relationships|date = August 14, 2014|accessdate = |website = The List Online, Daily Vista|publisher = List Partners, Inc.|last = Josh|first = Stone}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url = http://digest.dx3canada.com/2015/01/28/stay-together-for-the-work-creating-lasting-brand-agency-relationships-in-2015/|title = Stay Together For The Work: Creating Lasting Brand – Agency Relationships In 2015|date = January 28, 2015|accessdate = |website = dx3 digest|publisher = Dx3|last = Ben|first = Myers}}</ref> In addition, under his own private consulting firm, Fyshe leads a specialized client-agency relationship evaluation and performance measurement advisory serving some of Canada's leading brands.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.fysheandassoc.com/|title = Fyshe & Associates|date = January 27, 2015|accessdate = |website = Fyshe and Associates|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>
Fyshe lives in Toronto with his wife, Susan Fyshe MHSc RD, a nutritionist and registered dietitian.
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Fyshe, Mike}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1947 births]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Montreal]] [[Category:Businesspeople in advertising]] [[Category:Advertising people]] [[Category:Canadian marketing people]] [[Category:Canadian chief executives]]

{{Infobox organization | name = Namibia Chamber of Commerce and Industry | image = | image_border = | size = | caption = | map = | msize = | mcaption = | abbreviation = NCCI | motto = | formation = | extinction = | type = Financial Organization | status = | purpose = | headquarters = [[Windhoek]], [[Namibia]] | location = | region_served = | membership = 2500 (2013) | language = English | leader_title = President | leader_name = [[Sven Thieme]] | main_organ = Board of Governors | parent_organization = | affiliations = | num_staff = | num_volunteers = | budget = | website = {{URL|http://www.ncci.org.na }} | remarks = }} The '''Namibia Chamber of Commerce and Industry''' is the industrial and Chamber of Commerce in Namibia. It is headquartered in the capital [[Windhoek]]. In March 2013, the Chamber had about 2,500 members.<ref name="allafrica">{{cite web|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201405091580.html|title=allAfrica.com: Namibia: More Export Diversification Needed to Create Jobs|publisher=allafrica.com|accessdate=2014-05-11}}</ref>
==History== The Namibian Chamber of Commerce and Industry was established in 1990 as Namibia National Chamber of Commerce and Industry (NNCCI) in Windhoek. In 1998, the chamber was renamed and transferred to a legally independent, private-sector institution. As part of this realignment, the concept of regional chambers were implemented.<ref name="allafrica2">{{cite web|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201405091612.html|title=allAfrica.com: Namibia: Investment Climate Has Improved - NCCI, NMA Says (Page 1 of 2)|publisher=allafrica.com|accessdate=2014-05-11}}</ref>
==Tasks and Structure == NCCI is a non-profit organization whose mission is to represent the Namibian business enterprises from all economic sectors. It was on the basis of the Companies Act, Act no. 32 of 1973 established as a state institution. Additional areas of responsibility of the NCCI counts: *Legal Contact *Organizing and conducting conferences and trade shows *Issues of trade *Information gathering and reporting *Further education
Supreme establishment of the Namibian Chamber of the General Assembly, which convenes twice a year. The Board of Directors is the highest supervisory organ. It is composed of 14 members. The Chairman is the President, {{As of|2014|alt=currently}} [[Sven Thieme]].<ref>{{cite news | title=NCCI elects new leadership | date=1 July 2015 | newspaper=[[The Namibian]] | url=http://www.namibian.com.na/index.php?id=125094}}</ref> Another body of the Chamber is to represent the regional chambers. In daily business, the NCCI is led by the Secretariat. This is the Chief Executive Officer, currently [[Tarah Shaanika]].
The Namibia Chamber of Commerce and Industry is represented at regional and local level through regional chambers. These deal mainly with local issues. Regional chambers are (as of April 2011) in Arandis, Gobabis, Katima Mulilo, Keetmanshoop, Luderitz, Omaruru, Ongwediva, Oranjemund, Otjiwarongo, Rehoboth, Rosh Pinah, Rundu, Swakopmund,<ref name="newera">{{cite web|url=http://www.newera.com.na/2014/04/28/ncci-swakopmund-branch-elects-exco/|title=NCCI Swakopmund branch elects new exco|publisher=newera.com.na|accessdate=2014-05-11}}</ref> Tsumeb, Walvis Bay and Windhoek.
==Membership== The Namibian Chamber of Commerce and Industry has no system of compulsory membership. Membership is open to all Namibian companies but differs for micro, small and medium-sized enterprises and large corporations. In addition, there are special memberships for diplomats and associated facilities.
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
[[Category:Chambers of commerce]] [[Category:Economy of Namibia]] [[Category:Business organisations based in Namibia]] [[Category:1990 establishments in Namibia]]

{{Infobox company | name = Polaris Partners | logo = Polaris Partners Logo.jpg | logo_size = 250px | type = [[Private company|Private ownership]] | predecessor = [[Burr, Egan, Deleage & Co.]] | foundation = 1996 | location = [[Boston, Massachusetts]], [[United States]] | industry = [[Venture Capital]] | products = [[Venture capital]] | key_people = Managing Partners David Barrett, Brian Chee, Amir Nashat and Bryce Youngren | num_employees = 35+<ref name=whoweare>[http://www.polarisventures.com/WhoWeAre/Default.asp Polaris Venture Website: Who We Are] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081218142417/http://www.polarisventures.com/WhoWeAre/Default.asp |date=2008-12-18 }}</ref> | aum = $4.0 billion | homepage = [http://www.polarispartners.com polarispartners.com] }}
'''Polaris Partners''' is an investment firm that has partnered with entrepreneurs in the fields of healthcare and technology. The firm has partnered with enterprises in various stages of development.
Polaris has offices in Boston, Massachusetts and San Francisco, California. The firm has over $4 billion under management and has invested in more than 250 companies.<ref>{{cite web|title=Polaris Partners Portfolio|url=http://www.polarispartners.com/portfolio/}}</ref>
==History== Polaris Partners was founded in 1995/1996 by [[Jon Flint]], [[Terry McGuire]], [[Steve Arnold (Venture Capitalist)|Steve Arnold]], who were partners of [[Burr, Egan, Deleage & Co.]] (BEDCO).
{{history of private equity and venture capital}} Polaris was the first of four successors to [[Burr, Egan, Deleage & Co.]] (BEDCO), one of the earliest bi-coastal venture capital firms in the US, which dissolved in 1996. The firm has roughly $4.0 billion under management, and is now making investments through its seventh fund.
==See also== *[[Burr, Egan, Deleage & Co.]] *[[Alta Partners]] *[[Alta Communications]] *[[Focus Financial Partners]]
== References == <references /> *[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=990CEED9153DF936A15756C0A963958260 A Generation Gap in Venture Capital] *Gupta, Udayan. [https://books.google.com/books?id=xU7f9Jtq-3UC&pg=PA269 Done Deals: Venture Capitalists Tell Their Stories], 2000 *[http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-77251355.html Venture-Capital Firms Prepare for Next Generation of Partners] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20081019003600/http://www.ta.com/news/news_detail.asp?id=45 "The Thrill of Defeat"]. The Boston Globe, February 2001 *[http://www.wpen.org/article.html?aid=237 Cocktails & Conversation with Bill Egan, Alta Communications]. [[Wharton School of Business]], 2006.
==External links== *[http://www.polarisventures.com Polaris Partners]
{{Venture capital firms}}

{{no footnotes|date=January 2013}} [[File:Rainer Nõlvak, 2012.jpg|thumb|right|Rainer Nõlvak in 2012.]] '''Rainer Nõlvak''' is an [[Estonia]]n entrepreneur and nature protector who is Chairman of the board of [[Estonian Nature Fund]].
Rainer Nõlvak has advocated for the Estonian energy industry to move away from [[oil shale]] and move towards renewable energy systems. He has published the "Green Energy" program.
He was among the organizers of [[Let's Do It 2008]], a civic action with 50 000 volunteers participating in cleaning up the countryside of [[Estonia]] in one day. Because of this he received the 2008 [[Estonian Volunteer of the Year]] national award. The movement has initiated the global [[Let's Do It! World]] action.
He founded the following companies: Microlink Baltics, Curonia Research, Celecure.
==References== {{BLP unsourced|date=October 2016}} {{reflist}}
==External links== * http://www.elfond.ee/en * http://www.microlink.ee * http://www.curonia.com * http://www.letsdoitworld.org
{{DEFAULTSORT:Nolvak, Rainer}} [[Category:Estonian businesspeople]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Estonian environmentalists]]
